Authors: He Y., Le W., Zhong Y.
Title: Can Subsidies for New Energy Vehicles Drive Sales Growth? Based on the Empirical Study of PVAR model
Source title: Proceedings of the 2019 International Conference on Industrial Engineering and Systems Management, IESM 2019
Affiliations: China Jiliang University, Academy of Economics and Management, Hangzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: He, Y., China Jiliang University, Academy of Economics and Management, Hangzhou, China; Le, W., China Jiliang University, Academy of Economics and Management, Hangzhou, China; Zhong, Y., China Jiliang University, Academy of Economics and Management, Hangzhou, China
Abstract: The relationship between the sales volume of differently efficiency vehicle and purchase subsidy was analyzed using the PVAR model based on panel data of 35 vehicles' types of 6 enterprises in 33 months from 2016 to 2018. The study showed that purchase subsidies have a positive impact on the sales of high-efficiency vehicles continuously and the effect on low-efficiency vehicles changes from positive to negative over time. The result of variance decomposition also shows that subsidies contribute highly rate to the sales of high-efficiency vehicles. National subsidy policy should be adjusted to focus on high-efficiency vehicles and encourage the product with high technical level, such as long driving range and great battery system quality vehicles. And vehicles with inefficient power and poor quality should be phase out. Through these measures, the goals that purchase subsidies can promote enterprise's core technical ability and the effect of the 'quantity' to 'quality' can be achieved. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: High-efficiency vehicle; New energy vehicles; Purchase subsidies; PVAR model
Index Keywords: Digital storage; Electric vehicles; Battery systems; Driving range; Empirical studies; High-efficiency; Model-based OPC; New energy vehicles; Technical levels; Variance decomposition; Sales

Authors: Vasetsky Y., Mazurenko I.
Title: Stray Magnetic Fields of Toroidal Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES)
Source title: 2019 IEEE 20th International Conference on Computational Problems of Electrical Engineering, CPEE 2019
Affiliations: Institute of Electrodynamics, National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine, Kyiv, Ukraine
Authors with affiliations: Vasetsky, Y., Institute of Electrodynamics, National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine, Kyiv, Ukraine; Mazurenko, I., Institute of Electrodynamics, National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine, Kyiv, Ukraine
Abstract: The stray magnetic fields of toroidal superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) as a system of individual coils are considered. It is shown that the stray field depends on both the number of coils, size coils, its relative position and also required dimensions and coil currents. To determine dimension characteristics, it is advisable to use the idealized model of the toroidal current surface. For approximate estimate of the stray field can be used simplified model of unidirectional current filaments. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: stray magnetic fields; toroidal discrete winding; toroidal superconducting magnetic energy storage
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Magnetic fields; Superconducting coils; Superconducting magnets; Coil current; Current filaments; Idealized models; Relative positions; Stray field; Stray magnetic fields; Superconducting magnetic energy storages; Toroidal currents; Magnetic storage

Authors: Bintoudi A.D., Timplalexis C., Mendes G., Guerrero J.M., Demoulias C.
Title: Design of Space Microgrid for Manned Lunar Base: Spinning-in Terrestrial Technologies
Source title: 2019 European Space Power Conference, ESPC 2019
Affiliations: Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Thessaloniki, Greece; School of Energy Systems, Lappeenranta-Lahti University of Technology, Lappeenranta, Finland; Aalborg University, Department of Energy Technology, Aalborg, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Bintoudi, A.D., Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Thessaloniki, Greece; Timplalexis, C., Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Thessaloniki, Greece; Mendes, G., School of Energy Systems, Lappeenranta-Lahti University of Technology, Lappeenranta, Finland; Guerrero, J.M., Aalborg University, Department of Energy Technology, Aalborg, Denmark; Demoulias, C., Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Thessaloniki, Greece
Abstract: The present study analyses the design of the power system of a manned lunar base, in Shackleton crater, using well-established terrestrial technologies deriving from DC microgrids with increased fault-Tolerance needs. Expected luminance data from 2020 is used in order to select the ideal base location in terms of mean annual solar Irradiance, according to which, the sizing of the power generation and storage units is performed. The proposed grid topology is meshed in order to satisfy the high reliability requirements of a manned space mission and, at the same time, to reduce the mass/ volume budgets of the mission. The load profile is constructed using a set of notional loads. Furthermore, a novel solar array configuration is proposed under the scope of maximizing the energy production under the specific irradiance of the base siting. After preliminary sizing is performed, a series of microgrid-related technologies is suggested, covering all levels of grid design, control and protection. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: lunar manned base; microgrid; spin-in
Index Keywords: Budget control; Digital storage; Fault tolerance; Moon; Solar cell arrays; Spacecraft power supplies; Control and protection; Energy productions; High reliability; Luminance data; lunar manned base; Manned space mission; Micro grid; Solar irradiances; Moon bases

Authors: Kewat S., Singh B.
Title: Grid Synchronization of WEC-PV-BES Based Distributed Generation System using Robust Control Strategy
Source title: 2019 IEEE Industry Applications Society Annual Meeting, IAS 2019
Authors with affiliations: Kewat, S.; Singh, B.
Abstract: This paper deals with a distributed generation system (DGS) for managing the operation in grid connected and islanded mode. The DGS consists of wind turbine driven squirrel cage induction generator (SCIG), solar PV (Photovoltaic) array and battery energy storage (BES). A second order sequence (SOS) based FLL (Frequency Locked Loop) is used to estimate the grid and load voltage angles for fast and seamless grid synchronization. Moreover, in the grid-connected mode, the DC-link voltage control with the feed-forward term is made the DGS more effective under sudden load and solar power perturbation. The proposed LC (Load Converter) control algorithm is based on IAPV (Improved Affine Projection Versoria) adaptive filter and it is used to mitigate the harmonics from grid currents, to compensate the load reactive power and to provide the unity power factor in grid-connected mode. Moreover, the MC (Machine Converter) is used to extract the wind power with improved current quality of SCIG. The proposed control strategy of DGS, is validated at steady-state and dynamic disturbances. The DGS power quality indices are found well within the IEEE-1547 standard under grid-connected, standalone, and during reconnection of the grid. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Distributed Generation System; Load converter; Machine Converter and Power Quality; Synchronization
Index Keywords: Adaptive filtering; Adaptive filters; Asynchronous generators; Distributed power generation; Electric fault currents; Electric power system interconnection; Electric power transmission networks; Power converters; Power quality; Robust control; Solar energy; Solar power generation; Synchronization; Wind power; Battery energy storages (BES); DC link voltage control; Distributed generation system; Dynamic disturbances; Frequency locked loops; Grid synchronizations; Power quality indices; Squirrel cage induction generators; Electric power system control

Authors: Rikkas E.R.
Title: Preferable and feasible electricity corporate community concept for three generation types in metropolitan area in Finland
Source title: International Conference on the European Energy Market, EEM
Affiliations: Aalto University, School of Engineering, Otakaari 4, Espoo, 02150, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Rikkas, E.R., Aalto University, School of Engineering, Otakaari 4, Espoo, 02150, Finland
Abstract: The paper provides an overview of possible Electricity Corporate Communities to emerge depending on following generations: Generation X (born 1965-1976), Generation Y (born 1977-1995) and Generation Z (born 1996-current time). Two other types, Baby Boomers (born 1946-1964) and Traditionalists Generation (born 1945 and before) were excluded from study case. The reason lies in the selected areas where the working generation's age is younger than age of 55 years.The aim of the study results from the author's previous paper titled 'Standalone Electrical Storages as part of the Network System in Metropolitan Area in Finland.' In the current study, the areas are the same as in the mentioned paper: Pasila-Vallilla-Sörnäinen-Kalasatama (Helsinki), Keilaniemi-Otaniemi-Tapiola-Niittykumpu-Olari-Matinkylä (Espoo), and Aviapolis (Vantaa).The author formed a concept suitable for all three mentioned above generations relying on a conducted survey and various existing studies on consumer behavior of generation types. The author expected the result to confirm that the preferences, even in the energy field, are also subject to consumer behavior of generation types. © 2019 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Commerce; Power markets; Corporate community; Energy fields; Generation types; Generation Y; Metropolitan area; Network systems; Study case; Three generations; Consumer behavior

Authors: Zeng Y., Li H., Zhang Z., Zheng T.Q., Shang Z., Qiu Z., Yuan L., Ding Y.
Title: A Parallel-Resonant Isolated Bidirectional DC-DC Converter with Low Current Ripple for Battery Storage Systems
Source title: 2019 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2019
Affiliations: Beijing Jiaotong Universtiy, School of Electrical Engineering, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Zeng, Y., Beijing Jiaotong Universtiy, School of Electrical Engineering, Beijing, China; Li, H., Beijing Jiaotong Universtiy, School of Electrical Engineering, Beijing, China; Zhang, Z., Beijing Jiaotong Universtiy, School of Electrical Engineering, Beijing, China; Zheng, T.Q., Beijing Jiaotong Universtiy, School of Electrical Engineering, Beijing, China; Shang, Z., Beijing Jiaotong Universtiy, School of Electrical Engineering, Beijing, China; Qiu, Z., Beijing Jiaotong Universtiy, School of Electrical Engineering, Beijing, China; Yuan, L., Beijing Jiaotong Universtiy, School of Electrical Engineering, Beijing, China; Ding, Y., Beijing Jiaotong Universtiy, School of Electrical Engineering, Beijing, China
Abstract: In this paper, a parallel-resonant isolated bidirectional DC-DC converter with low current ripple and high voltage gain is proposed for the battery storage systems. In the low voltage side, the interleaved boost unit is employed to reduce the current ripple for improving the lifetime of battery. And the parallel resonant capacitor of transformer is used to achieve the soft-switching operation and recycle the energy of leakage inductance for improving efficiency. In the high voltage side, the dc-blocking capacitor is applied to increase voltage gain by reducing the voltage on the transformer. The proposed converter can achieve high conversion ratio with high efficiency. Moreover, it only contains four switches. Operation principle analysis and parameters design of the proposed converter are discussed in detail, which are validated by simulation. Finally, a 1kW experimental prototype is built to verify the advantages of the proposed converter. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Battery storage systems; Bidirectional; Isolated DC-DC converter; Parallel-resonant

Authors: Xia S., Ding Z., Du T., Zhang D., Yin H.
Title: Multi-time scale coordinated scheduling for the combined system of wind power, photovoltaic, thermal generator, hydro pumped storage and batteries
Source title: 2019 IEEE Industry Applications Society Annual Meeting, IAS 2019
Affiliations: School of Electrical Electronic Engineering, North China Electric Power University, Changping District, Beijing, 102206, China
Authors with affiliations: Xia, S., School of Electrical Electronic Engineering, North China Electric Power University, Changping District, Beijing, 102206, China; Ding, Z., School of Electrical Electronic Engineering, North China Electric Power University, Changping District, Beijing, 102206, China; Du, T., School of Electrical Electronic Engineering, North China Electric Power University, Changping District, Beijing, 102206, China; Zhang, D., School of Electrical Electronic Engineering, North China Electric Power University, Changping District, Beijing, 102206, China; Yin, H., School of Electrical Electronic Engineering, North China Electric Power University, Changping District, Beijing, 102206, China
Abstract: Grid connection of random renewable energy such as wind power and photovoltaic results in difficulties of keeping power balance for power system operation. In order to solve this problem, this paper proposed a multi-time scale coordinated scheduling model for the combined system of Wind power-Photovoltaic-Thermal generator-Hydro pumped storage-Battery (WPTHB) by taking advantages of their complementary operation characteristics. The scheduling model is composed of three time scales: the day-ahead scheduling, the 1-hour ahead scheduling and 15-minute ahead scheduling. 1) in the day-ahead scheduling, based on the day-ahead forecast data of Wind-Photovoltaic power and Load demand (WPL), the optimal power outputs of thermal power units in 24 hours are solved from a mix integer linear programing (MILP) model to achieve the minimal operation cost of thermal units. 2) In the 1-hour ahead scheduling, based on power outputs of thermal units solved in the day-ahead scheduling and the 1-hour-ahead forecasted WPL, the hydro pumped storage power output is optimized to achieve its minimal operation cost. 3) In the 15-minute ahead scheduling, based on the day-ahead optimal power outputs of thermal units and the 1-hour ahead optimal outputs of pumped storages, the battery optimal power generation is obtained from a AC optimal power flow model solved by MATPOWER. Simulations of New England system validate that the proposed multi-time scale coordinated scheduling model could fully explore the different power regulation speeds and capacity of hydro pumped storages, thermal power generators and batteries to effectively alleviate WPL variations and achieve economic operation for multi-source generation systems. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: 1-hour ahead scheduling; 15-minute ahead scheduling; AC-optimal power flow; coordinated scheduling model; day-ahead scheduling; mix integer linear programing; Multi-time scale
Index Keywords: Acoustic generators; Digital storage; Electric batteries; Electric load flow; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Energy policy; Fossil fuel power plants; Hydroelectric generators; Integer programming; Operating costs; Photovoltaic cells; Scheduling; Time measurement; Wind power; Ac optimal power flows; Coordinated scheduling; Day-ahead scheduling; Integer linear programing; Multi-time scale; Battery storage

Authors: Shi B., Zhao Z., Wei S., Zhang C.
Title: Self-Correction and Dead-Beat Current Control Strategy for Digital Programmed Boost Converter
Source title: 2019 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2019
Affiliations: Tsinghua University, Department of Electrical Engineering, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Shi, B., Tsinghua University, Department of Electrical Engineering, Beijing, China; Zhao, Z., Tsinghua University, Department of Electrical Engineering, Beijing, China; Wei, S., Tsinghua University, Department of Electrical Engineering, Beijing, China; Zhang, C., Tsinghua University, Department of Electrical Engineering, Beijing, China
Abstract: Boost converters are widely used for photovoltaic power generation, energy storage and electric vehicles. Dead-beat current control strategy, one of the most attractive digital current control strategies, enables the inductor current to reach the current reference in a minimal finite number of sampling cycles among digital current control strategies. However, steady state error and dynamic performance compromise will be introduced due to parameter mismatches. In this paper, based on a quantitative analysis for parameter mismatches' influence on steady state error and dynamic response, a self-correction and dead-beat current control algorithm is proposed to achieve both fast dynamic response and zero steady state error. The steady state error is eliminated by identifying system parameters with a least squares algorithm with forgetting factor. The dynamic response is fast with dead-beat control, enabling the inductor current to reach the current reference in quite few sampling cycles. The above two advantages of the proposed control algorithm is verified by experimental results with a 450 V - 7.0 kW prototype. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Boost converter; Dead-beat control; Parameter identification; Self-correction; Steady and dynamic performance

Authors: Deng J., Wang H.
Title: Hybrid modulated bidirectional resonant DC/DC converter for high-voltage bus-based energy storage systems
Source title: 2019 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2019
Affiliations: ShanghaiTech University, School of Information Science and Technology, Shanghai, China
Authors with affiliations: Deng, J., ShanghaiTech University, School of Information Science and Technology, Shanghai, China; Wang, H., ShanghaiTech University, School of Information Science and Technology, Shanghai, China
Abstract: In high-voltage bus-based energy storage systems, an isolated bidirectional dc/dc converter is required to link the low voltage energy storage unit and the high-voltage bus. This paper proposes a series resonant dc/dc converter for this specific application. In the proposed converter, the step-up ratio is boosted by an active voltage quadrupler rectifier on the high voltage side. Thus, a transformer with a moderate turns ratio can be employed. Moreover, the voltage stresses of high voltage side MOSFETs are significantly reduced in comparison with conventional active rectifiers. This facilitates an easier selection of low-cost and highly-reliable Si MOSFETs. To optimize the converter performance, a unique phase-shift and frequency hybrid modulation scheme are proposed. The frequency modulation tightly regulates the output power, while the phase-shit modulation minimizes the conduction loss. A 500 W converter prototype, linking an 80 V-120 V battery pack and 760 V dc bus, is designed and tested to verify the concept. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Bidirectional dc/dc converter; Phase-shift-modulation (PSM); Variable frequency modulation (VFM)

Authors: Biroon R.A., Abdollahi Z., Hadidi R.
Title: Fast and Regular Electric Vehicle Charging Impacts on the Distribution Feeders
Source title: 2019 IEEE Industry Applications Society Annual Meeting, IAS 2019
Authors with affiliations: Biroon, R.A.; Abdollahi, Z.; Hadidi, R.
Abstract: In recent years, integration of renewable energy sources to the traditional power system has involved the attention of researchers as well as industries. Due to the limited availability of renewable energy sources e.g. solar, accompanying energy storage systems e.g. battery with renewables is a must. Electric Vehicles (EVs) as a major consumer of the batteries, have a considerable influence on the power grids. Therefore, smart charging profiles of the electric vehicles as battery storage systems, play a substantial role in the power system energy management. Considering the notable share of the commercial sector in the power grid peak along with the electric vehicles (EVs) growth, potential impacts of EVs on stability and operation of the power grid should be taken into account. In this paper, we develop an optimization algorithm for a commercial customer to investigate the effect of the EV connection to the grid under different charging modes along with the consideration of the tariff. To simulate the average EV trip, an arbitrary load profile based on EV consumption rate has been defined. Simulation results show that the customer's load profile is highly affected by the electricity tariff and the EV charging methods. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: electric vehicles (EVs); fast charging; optimization; power exchange; regular charging; tariff; vehicle to grid (V2G) connection
Index Keywords: Charging (batteries); Commercial vehicle operations; Commercial vehicles; Electric energy storage; Electric power transmission networks; Electric vehicles; Natural resources; Optimization; Renewable energy resources; Secondary batteries; Vehicle-to-grid; Electric Vehicles (EVs); Fast charging; Power exchange; tariff; Vehicle to Grid (V2G); Electric power system stability

Authors: Farinet D., Maurer M., Vacca L., Spataru S.V., Stroe D.-I.
Title: Battery Lifetime Analysis for Residential PV-Battery System used to Optimize the Self Consumption - A Danish Scenario
Source title: 2019 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2019
Affiliations: Aalborg University, Department of Energy Technology, Aalborg, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Farinet, D., Aalborg University, Department of Energy Technology, Aalborg, Denmark; Maurer, M., Aalborg University, Department of Energy Technology, Aalborg, Denmark; Vacca, L., Aalborg University, Department of Energy Technology, Aalborg, Denmark; Spataru, S.V., Aalborg University, Department of Energy Technology, Aalborg, Denmark; Stroe, D.-I., Aalborg University, Department of Energy Technology, Aalborg, Denmark
Abstract: Residential photovoltaic (PV) systems with integrated battery energy storage (BES) are used to increase energy self-consumption, especially in countries with low feed-in tariffs and high electricity prices. In recent years, lithium-ion batteries have been established as common technology for this application. However, a major challenge is their performance degradation over time, which is influenced by how the BES is operated. In this work, the impact of the PV + BES system's Energy Management System (EMS) on the lifetime of the battery is investigated, by developing a performance model of the PV+BES system and analyzing the battery degradation under different operation scenarios, using a battery lifetime model. Simulation results show that the battery lifetime can be extended and a high self-consumption ratio achieved, by operating the EMS at different charging rates, depending on predicted future PV production based on weather forecast. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Battery; Battery Lifetime; Photovoltaics; Residential System; Self Consumption

Authors: Liu Y., Huang Z., Liao H., Li H., Wu Y., Zhou Y., Jiang F., Peng J.
Title: A lifetime-aware control strategy for parallel charging systems of energy storage light rail
Source title: 2019 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2019
Affiliations: Central South University, School of Automation, Changsha, 410083, China; School of Computer Science and Engineering, Central South University, Changsha, 410083, China; Hunan Engineering Laboratory of Rail Vehicles Braking Technology, Changsha, 410083, China
Authors with affiliations: Liu, Y., Central South University, School of Automation, Changsha, 410083, China, Hunan Engineering Laboratory of Rail Vehicles Braking Technology, Changsha, 410083, China; Huang, Z., Central South University, School of Automation, Changsha, 410083, China, Hunan Engineering Laboratory of Rail Vehicles Braking Technology, Changsha, 410083, China; Liao, H., School of Computer Science and Engineering, Central South University, Changsha, 410083, China, Hunan Engineering Laboratory of Rail Vehicles Braking Technology, Changsha, 410083, China; Li, H., School of Computer Science and Engineering, Central South University, Changsha, 410083, China, Hunan Engineering Laboratory of Rail Vehicles Braking Technology, Changsha, 410083, China; Wu, Y., Central South University, School of Automation, Changsha, 410083, China, Hunan Engineering Laboratory of Rail Vehicles Braking Technology, Changsha, 410083, China; Zhou, Y., Central South University, School of Automation, Changsha, 410083, China, Hunan Engineering Laboratory of Rail Vehicles Braking Technology, Changsha, 410083, China; Jiang, F., School of Computer Science and Engineering, Central South University, Changsha, 410083, China, Hunan Engineering Laboratory of Rail Vehicles Braking Technology, Changsha, 410083, China; Peng, J., School of Computer Science and Engineering, Central South University, Changsha, 410083, China, Hunan Engineering Laboratory of Rail Vehicles Braking Technology, Changsha, 410083, China
Abstract: Recent years have seen growing interest in energy storage light rail where multi-module charging system is used to realize high power fast charging. In existing methods, each module supplies the same current to charge onboard super-capacitors. However, this current sharing method will increase maintenance frequency of the charging system and accelerate the modules aging speed, because it does not consider the different degradation degree among modules. In this paper, a lifetime-aware current control strategy is proposed for addressing the above issues. First, a data-driven remaining useful life (RUL) estimation algorithm based on a linear approximation model is proposed. Second, the currents supplied by all modules are allocated by a proportional current control strategy based on the RUL estimation algorithm. Experimental results show that the proposed method has the advantages of narrowing the degradation differences among modules and reducing the heat dissipation, compared to the current sharing mode. © 2019 IEEE.

Authors: Mao M., Jiang X., Liu Y., Chang L., Wang Y.
Title: Generalized energy storage configuration method based on bi-level optimization for distribution power system with high penetration of renewable energy
Source title: 2019 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2019
Affiliations: Hefei University of Technology, Research Center for Photovoltaic System Engineering, Hefei, China
Authors with affiliations: Mao, M., Hefei University of Technology, Research Center for Photovoltaic System Engineering, Hefei, China; Jiang, X., Hefei University of Technology, Research Center for Photovoltaic System Engineering, Hefei, China; Liu, Y., Hefei University of Technology, Research Center for Photovoltaic System Engineering, Hefei, China; Chang, L., Hefei University of Technology, Research Center for Photovoltaic System Engineering, Hefei, China; Wang, Y., Hefei University of Technology, Research Center for Photovoltaic System Engineering, Hefei, China
Abstract: In the power system, controllable loads which can store thermal energy, potential energy and electric energy can be used as virtual energy storage systems (VESS) and form generalized energy storage systems (GESS) along with the stationary energy storage systems (SESS) composed by batteries. In view of the GESS configuration problem for distribution power system with high penetration of renewable energy, this paper proposes bi-level optimization method to reduce the stationary energy storage configuration demand by introducing VESS. The external model of the bi-level optimization model uses the genetic algorithm to search for the GESS configuration scheme, and the internal model is used to optimize the operation strategy of the GESS based on the dynamic programming algorithm. The simulation results for a distribution system with different penetration rate of renewable energy show that the configuration cost of stationery battery energy storage systems can be significantly reduced by the proposed method with considering the controllable loads, specifically for higher penetration of renewable energy. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Bi-level optimization; Configuration problem; Generalized energy storage systems; Renewable energy

Authors: Tian Q., Zhou G., Leng M., Fan X., Yan T.
Title: A Novel Dual-input Dual-output Converter and Dynamic Energy Management for PV/Battery Systems
Source title: 2019 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2019
Affiliations: Southwest Jiaotong University, School of Electrical Engineering, Chengdu, China; Xihua University, School of Electrical Engineering and Electronic Information, Chengdu, China
Authors with affiliations: Tian, Q., Southwest Jiaotong University, School of Electrical Engineering, Chengdu, China; Zhou, G., Southwest Jiaotong University, School of Electrical Engineering, Chengdu, China; Leng, M., Southwest Jiaotong University, School of Electrical Engineering, Chengdu, China; Fan, X., Southwest Jiaotong University, School of Electrical Engineering, Chengdu, China; Yan, T., Xihua University, School of Electrical Engineering and Electronic Information, Chengdu, China
Abstract: In photovoltaic (PV) / battery power systems, using a multiple-port converter (MPC) instead of several single-input converters has advantages of simpler circuit, higher efficiency and lower cost. A novel dual-input dual-output (DIDO) converter as well as its operating principle are analyzed in this paper. A dynamic energy management and control method based on inductor current ripple is further proposed for PV/battery system, which can maintain maximum power point tracking (MPPT) operation of PV module and constant bus voltage at the same time. The implementation of the control method is described in detail. Derivation of voltage gain and the conditions for the converter to work on continuous conduction mode (CCM) are provided to guide parameter design. Finally, simulation verifications for different demands of PV power and load power are given to illustrate the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed topology and control method. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Energy management and control; Energy storage system; Multiple-port converter; Photovoltaic generation

Authors: Liu L., Han P., Sun W., Wu D., Mai R., He Z.
Title: A Series-Parallel Switched-Capacitor Equalizer for the Hybrid Energy Storage System
Source title: 2019 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2019
Affiliations: Southwest Jiaotong University, Department of Electrical Engineering, Chengdu, China
Authors with affiliations: Liu, L., Southwest Jiaotong University, Department of Electrical Engineering, Chengdu, China; Han, P., Southwest Jiaotong University, Department of Electrical Engineering, Chengdu, China; Sun, W., Southwest Jiaotong University, Department of Electrical Engineering, Chengdu, China; Wu, D., Southwest Jiaotong University, Department of Electrical Engineering, Chengdu, China; Mai, R., Southwest Jiaotong University, Department of Electrical Engineering, Chengdu, China; He, Z., Southwest Jiaotong University, Department of Electrical Engineering, Chengdu, China
Abstract: The hybrid energy storage system (HESS) automatic equalization based on series-parallel switched-capacitor converter is presented in this paper. The advantage of the proposed system is that ultra-capacitors and battery-pack can achieve balanced simultaneously, which realizes the energy exchanging between two kinds of cell. Moreover, series-parallel switched-capacitor equalizer is proposed to achieve high balancing speed regardless of the cell number or their position in HESS. Only one balancing circuit is needed which can lower size and cost. An experimental prototype of 2 series-connected lithiumion batteries and 4 series-connected ultra-capacitor is built, the experimental results verify that the proposed equalizer can achieve balance of both ultra-capacitors and battery-pack. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Battery equalization; Management system (BMS); Switches- capacitor; Voltage balance

Authors: Li Z., Yang X., Tao H., Zheng T.Q., You X., Kobrle P.
Title: Improved modular multilevel converter with symmetrical integrated super capacitor energy storage system for electrical energy router application
Source title: 2019 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2019
Affiliations: Beijing Jiaotong University, School of Electrical Engineering, Beijing, China; Czech Technical University, Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Czech Republic
Authors with affiliations: Li, Z., Beijing Jiaotong University, School of Electrical Engineering, Beijing, China; Yang, X., Beijing Jiaotong University, School of Electrical Engineering, Beijing, China; Tao, H., Beijing Jiaotong University, School of Electrical Engineering, Beijing, China; Zheng, T.Q., Beijing Jiaotong University, School of Electrical Engineering, Beijing, China; You, X., Beijing Jiaotong University, School of Electrical Engineering, Beijing, China; Kobrle, P., Czech Technical University, Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Czech Republic
Abstract: An improved modular multilevel converter with symmetrical integrated super capacitor energy storage system (IMMC-SSCESS) is proposed for interfacing energy interconnection and power buffering in electrical energy routers. Compared with traditional modular multilevel converter based distributed super capacitor energy storage system (MMC-DSCESS), the proposed IMMC-SSCESS increases the overall system rapidity and stability, reduces system control complexity and is suitable for energy storage system (ESS) management. Based on analysis of operation principles, the control algorithms are developed for both the sub-modules (SMs) capacitor voltage control and super capacitor state of charge (SOC) balancing control. Feasibility of proposed topology and control strategies are verified by simulation and experiment results. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Improved modular multilevel converter; State of charge (SOC); Super capacitor energy storage system

Authors: Zhang Y., Liu Z., Kong J., Feng J., Zhao S., Dong L., Feng M., Hua Q.
Title: Power distribution and individual phase control of asymmetrical three-phase cascaded multilevel hybrid energy storage system in star configuration
Source title: 2019 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2019
Affiliations: Nanjing University of Science and Technology, School of Automation, Nanjing, China; Nanjing Rail Transit Systems Co., Ltd, Nanjing, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, Y., Nanjing University of Science and Technology, School of Automation, Nanjing, China; Liu, Z., Nanjing University of Science and Technology, School of Automation, Nanjing, China; Kong, J., Nanjing University of Science and Technology, School of Automation, Nanjing, China; Feng, J., Nanjing University of Science and Technology, School of Automation, Nanjing, China; Zhao, S., Nanjing University of Science and Technology, School of Automation, Nanjing, China; Dong, L., Nanjing University of Science and Technology, School of Automation, Nanjing, China; Feng, M., Nanjing University of Science and Technology, School of Automation, Nanjing, China; Hua, Q., Nanjing Rail Transit Systems Co., Ltd, Nanjing, China
Abstract: Considering the coupling among chains and links, a power distribution and individual phase control method is proposed for asymmetrical three-phase cascaded multilevel hybrid energy storage system in star configuration. Based on a three-phase system with battery and capacitor operating as two different sources, an individual phase control method is utilized to distribute active and reactive power in each phase independently. The stable operating range has been derived to avoid overmodulation, and common range of asymmetrical links is also obtained to achieve individual phase control. A 5MW/35kV system with proposed control strategy is experimented on RT-LAB platform to validate the feasibility of this method. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Asymmetrical; Multilevel Converter; System Fault; Vector Analysis

Authors: Zhang Z., Wu Z., Xie S., Ma X., Xu J., Liu M.
Title: A soft-switching current-fed isolated bidirectional DC-DC converter with low circulating power and easy-implemented control strategy
Source title: 2019 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2019
Affiliations: Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, College of Automation Engineering, Nanjing, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, Z., Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, College of Automation Engineering, Nanjing, China; Wu, Z., Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, College of Automation Engineering, Nanjing, China; Xie, S., Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, College of Automation Engineering, Nanjing, China; Ma, X., Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, College of Automation Engineering, Nanjing, China; Xu, J., Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, College of Automation Engineering, Nanjing, China; Liu, M., Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, College of Automation Engineering, Nanjing, China
Abstract: In the battery energy storage systems, the existing isolated bidirectional DC/DC converters fail to achieve high-efficiency because it is difficult to achieve soft-switching and low current stress simultaneously in the full operation range. A novel current-fed isolated bidirectional dc-dc converter with two transformers and two half bridges at the high voltage side is proposed to solve the problem. The PWM plus dual phase shift modulation (PPDPS) with voltage-match control is applied to keep peak and rms current of the transformers low. ZVS for most switches can be ensured by the control strategy, while practical ZVS for the rest switches is achieved by the magnetizing currents of the transformers. Therefore, low conduction losses and switching losses can be obtained in the proposed converter. The theoretical analysis and the soft-switching capability of the proposed converter are verified by the experimental results. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Battery; Bidirectional dc/dc converter; Efficiency; Magnetizing inductance; Soft-switching

Authors: Koltsaklis N.E., Panapakidis I.P., Christoforidis G.C., Parisses C.E.
Title: An MILP model for the optimal energy management of a smart household
Source title: International Conference on the European Energy Market, EEM
Affiliations: University of Western Macedonia, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Kozani, 50100, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Koltsaklis, N.E., University of Western Macedonia, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Kozani, 50100, Greece; Panapakidis, I.P., University of Western Macedonia, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Kozani, 50100, Greece; Christoforidis, G.C., University of Western Macedonia, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Kozani, 50100, Greece; Parisses, C.E., University of Western Macedonia, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Kozani, 50100, Greece
Abstract: This work presents a mixed integer linear programming (MILP) model for the optimal energy scheduling of a smart household. More specifically, the developed model determines the cost-optimal day-Ahead energy scheduling of all types of loads that can be either inflexible or can participate in demand response programs, as well as the charging/discharging programs of electric vehicle and energy storage. The studied energy system can also interact with the power grid, buying and/or selling electricity. The smart energy system includes also renewable generating facilities, namely a wind turbine and a photovoltaic panel, which produce electrical energy which can be either consumed for its own needs, utilized for charging requirements (storage, electric vehicles), or sold back to the power grid. The ultimate optimization goal concerns the optimal satisfaction of all types of loads with the objective of minimizing the total operational cost, satisfying simultaneously a series of technical constraints. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Demand response; Electric vehicles; Energy scheduling; Mixed integer linear programming; Smart home
Index Keywords: Automation; Commerce; Electric energy storage; Electric power transmission networks; Electric vehicles; Photovoltaic cells; Power markets; Scheduling; Charging/discharging; Demand response; Demand response programs; Mixed integer linear programming; Mixed integer linear programming model; Smart energy systems; Smart homes; Technical constraints; Integer programming

Authors: Evangelopoulou S., Kannavou M., Zazias G., Capros P.
Title: Model-based assessment of electricity storage in a european system producing hydrogen and hydrocarbons from renewable energy
Source title: International Conference on the European Energy Market, EEM
Affiliations: National Technical University of Athens, E3MLab-Energy Economy Environment Modelling Lab, 9 Iroon Polytechniou Str, Athens, 15773, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Evangelopoulou, S., National Technical University of Athens, E3MLab-Energy Economy Environment Modelling Lab, 9 Iroon Polytechniou Str, Athens, 15773, Greece; Kannavou, M., National Technical University of Athens, E3MLab-Energy Economy Environment Modelling Lab, 9 Iroon Polytechniou Str, Athens, 15773, Greece; Zazias, G., National Technical University of Athens, E3MLab-Energy Economy Environment Modelling Lab, 9 Iroon Polytechniou Str, Athens, 15773, Greece; Capros, P., National Technical University of Athens, E3MLab-Energy Economy Environment Modelling Lab, 9 Iroon Polytechniou Str, Athens, 15773, Greece
Abstract: The paper presents the methodology of modelling energy-system scenarios for the EU until 2050 focusing on carbon neutrality. The scenario assumptions include no-regret policy options such as energy efficiency, renewables and electrification. Disruptive changes, however, are needed in the energy system to reduce the unabated emissions remained by the implementation of the no-regret policies. The alternative disruptive changes include maximum electrification, hydrogen use or synthetic carbon-neutral hydrocarbons used as energy carriers. The enhanced PRIMES model presented in this paper includes all the options and the technologies enabling the energy transition towards a carbon-neutral EU economy by 2050. Despite that the quantified scenarios entail significant benefits, considerable uncertainties remain unexplored mainly regarding the costs of technologies and alternative fuels that are not industrially mature today. Reaching maturity requires a significant investment which depends on positive anticipation of market development. Policy guidance is required in order to assist in this direction. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Carbon neutral economy; electricity storage; energy transition; power-To-X; renewable fuels
Index Keywords: Alternative fuels; Carbon; Commerce; Electric energy storage; Electric utilities; Energy efficiency; Hydrocarbons; Hydrogen production; Hydrogen storage; Power markets; Carbon neutrals; Electricity storages; Energy transitions; power-To-X; Renewable fuels; Investments

Authors: Shi F., Li R.
Title: High Efficiency High Power Density Bidirectional DC-DC Converter for Photovoltaic Energy Storage System Utilization
Source title: 2019 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2019
Affiliations: Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Key Laboratory of Control of Power Transmission and Conversion, Shanghai, China
Authors with affiliations: Shi, F., Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Key Laboratory of Control of Power Transmission and Conversion, Shanghai, China; Li, R., Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Key Laboratory of Control of Power Transmission and Conversion, Shanghai, China
Abstract: In this paper, a high efficiency high power density bidirectional dc-dc converter with wide dc gain range face to photovoltaic energy storage system (PESS) based on the 24V battery module is proposed. The dc-dc converter uses two-stage topology, which meets the demand of wide gain range in PESS. The surface mounted devices (SMD) for synchronous rectification were used here to improve power density. The optimized design method of the converter is proposed. A 4kW prototype was built and the experimental results are given in the paper. The highest efficiency is up to 97.5% in charging mode and 96% in discharging mode. The power density of the converter can achieve 650W/L. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Bidirectional DC-DC converter; High efficiency; High power density; Photovoltaic energy storage system

Authors: Huang Z., Le Y., Liao H., Zhou Y., Wu Y., Li H., Li S., Lu X., Peng J.

Source title: 2019 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2019
Affiliations: Central South University, School of Automation, Changsha, 410083, China; School of Computer Science and Engineering, Central South University, Changsha, 410083, China; School of Electrical and Information Engineering, Changsha University of Science and Technology, Changsha, 410076, China; Hunan Engineering Laboratory of Rail Vehicles Braking Technology, Changsha, 410083, China
Authors with affiliations: Huang, Z., Central South University, School of Automation, Changsha, 410083, China, Hunan Engineering Laboratory of Rail Vehicles Braking Technology, Changsha, 410083, China; Le, Y., Central South University, School of Automation, Changsha, 410083, China, Hunan Engineering Laboratory of Rail Vehicles Braking Technology, Changsha, 410083, China; Liao, H., Central South University, School of Automation, Changsha, 410083, China, Hunan Engineering Laboratory of Rail Vehicles Braking Technology, Changsha, 410083, China; Zhou, Y., Central South University, School of Automation, Changsha, 410083, China, Hunan Engineering Laboratory of Rail Vehicles Braking Technology, Changsha, 410083, China; Wu, Y., Central South University, School of Automation, Changsha, 410083, China, Hunan Engineering Laboratory of Rail Vehicles Braking Technology, Changsha, 410083, China; Li, H., School of Computer Science and Engineering, Central South University, Changsha, 410083, China, Hunan Engineering Laboratory of Rail Vehicles Braking Technology, Changsha, 410083, China; Li, S., School of Electrical and Information Engineering, Changsha University of Science and Technology, Changsha, 410076, China, Hunan Engineering Laboratory of Rail Vehicles Braking Technology, Changsha, 410083, China; Lu, X., Central South University, School of Automation, Changsha, 410083, China, Hunan Engineering Laboratory of Rail Vehicles Braking Technology, Changsha, 410083, China; Peng, J., School of Computer Science and Engineering, Central South University, Changsha, 410083, China, Hunan Engineering Laboratory of Rail Vehicles Braking Technology, Changsha, 410083, China
Abstract: In the hybrid energy storage system of electric vehicles, the high-rate charge and discharge operations typically lead to the significant temperature rise of batteries, which degrades the lifetime of batteries and poses safety awareness. Thus, suppressing the battery temperature rise is of great importance to enforce the reliability and extend the cycling life of batteries. In this paper, we propose a temperature-suppression power allocation strategy to address this issue. Specifically, the pulse technique is integrated into the control loop to reduce the battery average current during each pulse period, which is able to suppress the battery temperature rise efficiently. Meanwhile, the pulse technique is combined with a designed filter-based power allocation algorithm to distribute load power for batteries and supercapacitors. The proposed strategy can suppress the battery temperature rise under the premise of meeting load power requirements. The EPA US06 driving cycles are applied in an experiment platform to verify the effectiveness of the proposed approach. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Battery temperature suppression; Electric vehicles; Hybrid energy management; Power allocation

Authors: Meng Y., Wang Y., Xiong M., Hu S., He X.
Title: Power Allocation for Energy Stored Quasi-Z-Source Inverter Based on the Power Loss Modelling
Source title: 2019 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2019
Affiliations: Zhejiang University, College of Electrical Engineering, Hangzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Meng, Y., Zhejiang University, College of Electrical Engineering, Hangzhou, China; Wang, Y., Zhejiang University, College of Electrical Engineering, Hangzhou, China; Xiong, M., Zhejiang University, College of Electrical Engineering, Hangzhou, China; Hu, S., Zhejiang University, College of Electrical Engineering, Hangzhou, China; He, X., Zhejiang University, College of Electrical Engineering, Hangzhou, China
Abstract: In this paper, convertor power loss modelling and its efficiency enhancement control strategies in the hybrid energy stored system (HESS) are studied. The energy stored quasi-Z-source inverter (ES-qZSI) is chosen to demonstrate a detailed power regulation method. According to the current commutation of the converter, the U-type power loss variation trend is found with the power allocation ratio. The expressions of power loss in both the system dc and ac side are presented to derive the loss trajectory mathematically. Both simulation and experimental results verify that within the efficiency enhancement range, more than 40% power loss get saved and the efficiency get increased by 8% with the proposed power allocation method. The analysis about the energy storage units embedding can also be applied for the optimal operation in other energy storage systems. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: ES-qZSI; HESS; Power allocation method; Power loss

Authors: Chandran V.P., Murshid S., Singh B.
Title: Power quality improvement in PMSG Based Hydro-BES system operating in isolated remote areas using CF-FLL control
Source title: 2019 IEEE Energy Conversion Congress and Exposition, ECCE 2019
Authors with affiliations: Chandran, V.P.; Murshid, S.; Singh, B.
Abstract: In this work, a hydro based autonomous energy conversion system supported by the battery energy storage (BES) is presented. A permanent magnet synchronous machine is used as a generator for hydro energy conversion. A 4-leg voltage source converter (VSC) connected to the point of common coupling (PCC) of this system, is used to control voltage, frequency and to improve power quality of this system. The overall control strategy compensates the neutral current and alleviates the effect of unbalance in three-phase 4-wire load using a 4-leg insulated gate bipolar transistor (IGBT) based VSC. The harmonic rejection capability of combined filter-frequency locked loop (CF-FLL) control technique is demonstrated through experimental results. The system achieves active power balance through charging and discharging of BES, which is coupled to a DC-link through a bidirectional DC/DC converter (BDC). Performance of presented system using the CF-FLL control strategy suppresses the effect of unbalanced nonlinear loading. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Hydro-BES system; PMSG; Power Quality; VSC and bidirectional DC/DC converter

Authors: Konstantinopoulos C., Avramiotis-Falireas I., Bolognani S., Gros D., Chacko A., Hug G.
Title: Reliability assessment of PV units in primary and secondary frequency control ancillary services
Source title: International Conference on the European Energy Market, EEM
Affiliations: Swissgrid Ltd, Aarau, 5001, Switzerland; Automatic Control Laboratory, ETH Zurich, Zurich, 8092, Switzerland; Energy Solutions AG, Olten, 4600, Switzerland; Power Systems Laboratory, ETH Zurich, Zurich, 8092, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Konstantinopoulos, C., Swissgrid Ltd, Aarau, 5001, Switzerland; Avramiotis-Falireas, I., Swissgrid Ltd, Aarau, 5001, Switzerland; Bolognani, S., Automatic Control Laboratory, ETH Zurich, Zurich, 8092, Switzerland; Gros, D., Energy Solutions AG, Olten, 4600, Switzerland; Chacko, A., Power Systems Laboratory, ETH Zurich, Zurich, 8092, Switzerland; Hug, G., Power Systems Laboratory, ETH Zurich, Zurich, 8092, Switzerland
Abstract: Recent studies have demonstrated how storage-less PV units have the technical capability to contribute to grid frequency control. However, system operators have stringent criteria for the dynamic response as well as the availability of the assets participating in these ancillary services. In this paper, we propose a methodology to assess and certify the impact of storage-less PV units on grid frequency regulation when the primary energy source availability is uncertain. The proposed approach is based on a first-principle dynamic model that is independent of the specific control strategy employed in the PV units, together with a statistical analysis of real data of power forecast error. The resulting methodology can be used to pre-qualify PV participation in the ancillary service market. The proposed approach is illustrated using real data and specifications from the Swiss transmission system operator. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Frequency control; primary and secondary control; PV forecast error.; PV units

Abstract: Digital control of the virtual synchronous generator contributes to improve the stability of the system. The discrete-time model of voltage source inverter with LC filter is analyzed and implemented in this paper. Then this paper designs the VSG control parameters in the discrete domain, considering a digital control method of seamless transformation without PLL. The experimental results verify the effectiveness of the proposed method. © 2019 EPE Association.

Authors: Frieden D., Roberts J., Gubina A.F.
Title: Overview of emerging regulatory frameworks on collective self-consumption and energy communities in Europe
Source title: International Conference on the European Energy Market, EEM
Affiliations: Andreas Tuerk Joanneum Research, Graz, Austria; Stanislas d'Herbemont RESCOOP, Brussels, Belgium; Benjamin Komel University of Ljubljana, Ljubljana, Slovenia
Authors with affiliations: Frieden, D., Andreas Tuerk Joanneum Research, Graz, Austria; Roberts, J., Stanislas d'Herbemont RESCOOP, Brussels, Belgium; Gubina, A.F., Benjamin Komel University of Ljubljana, Ljubljana, Slovenia
Abstract: Basic self-consumption has many limitations as the amount of investment is significantly lower than it could be if more members would have joined a sort of group or community. The same goes for the physical parameters of an energy-generating unit in a RES power plant. The bigger the PV power plant the bigger amount of generated electrical energy with just a small impact on the investment amount. Apartment blocks have larger roofs to accommodate larger units and enough members/users that are able and interested to contribute to a better environment and to lower their electricity bill. Technology also allows for a sufficient amount of storage of electrical energy and can contribute to secure supply of larger remote groups of buildings in harsh climate conditions. With proper regulatory frameworks in place, the final consumers can form energy communities as one way to participate in collective self-consumption activities. The aim of this review is to understand and compare the emerging regulatory frameworks with those already in place in EU member states. Some countries already made significant progress in the transposition process of the EU framework and thus comply with the provisions of the European Commissions' Clean Energy Package. Most countries, however, are in an early stage of transposition. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Clean Energy for all Europeans; Clean Energy Packet; Collective self-consumption; Energy community; Regulatory frameworks; RES Communities; Self-consumption
Index Keywords: Commerce; Power markets; Power plants; Clean energy; Collective self-consumption; Energy community; Regulatory frameworks; Self-consumption; Investments

Authors: Han X., Hug G.
Title: Distributionally Robust Distributed Generation Expansion Planning in a Market Environment
Source title: International Conference on the European Energy Market, EEM
Affiliations: ETH Zurich, Department of Information Technology and Electrical Engineering, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Han, X., ETH Zurich, Department of Information Technology and Electrical Engineering, Switzerland; Hug, G., ETH Zurich, Department of Information Technology and Electrical Engineering, Switzerland
Abstract: A generation expansion planning strategy to derive the optimal mix of distributed generations in a market environment is proposed. The considered system includes candidate decentralized storage units, variable generation units, dispatchable generation units and demand response. Distributionally robust optimization is applied to characterize the uncertainties in wind and PV generation forecasts by describing a family of possible uncertainty distributions with an ambiguity set. Finally, a multistage stochastic programming model is formulated to minimize the worst-case expectation of the sum of long-Term investment costs and short-Term operational costs. A case study based on Belgian electricity system data demonstrates the effectiveness of the proposed model and the importance of considering markets when optimizing the mix of distributed generation. The impacts of different products in reserve markets are analyzed and the outcomes from distributionally robust optimization, robust optimization and stochastic optimization are compared. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Decentralized energy resources; distributionally robust optimization; electricity markets; generation expansion planning; linear decision rule

Authors: Nigmatulina N., Tikka V., Belonogova N., Romanenko A., Honkapuro S.
Title: Scheduling of an Energy Storage System Operation with Regard to the Market Price Behavior
Source title: International Conference on the European Energy Market, EEM
Affiliations: LUT University, Lappeenranta, Finland; LUT University, Lappeenranta, Finland, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Nigmatulina, N., LUT University, Lappeenranta, Finland; Tikka, V., LUT University, Lappeenranta, Finland; Belonogova, N., LUT University, Lappeenranta, Finland, Finland; Romanenko, A., LUT University, Lappeenranta, Finland, Finland; Honkapuro, S., LUT University, Lappeenranta, Finland, Finland
Abstract: This paper presents a decision-making tool that enables multifunctional operation of a battery energy storage system (BESS) in combination with renewable energy sources (RES). In the framework of the tool implementation the operation of the BESS in combination with solar photovoltaic panels was studied on the Green Campus of LUT University, Finland. The set-up was adjusted to work in the day-Ahead and frequency regulation markets with a separate schedule for every season of the year. The results demonstrate the feasibility of establishing a software that enables operation of a BESS. The tests performed in the study indicate that the operation on the market of ancillary services is more profitable than in the day-Ahead market. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: battery energy storage system; day-Ahead market; distributed generation; frequency regulation

Authors: Layec V., Wache H.
Title: Flexible capacity addition case study at reduced grid tariff without security of supply
Source title: International Conference on the European Energy Market, EEM
Affiliations: Institute for Information Systems University of Applied Sciences and Arts Northwestern Switzerland, FHNW, Olten, 4600, Switzerland; Institute for Information Systems FHNW, Olten, 4600, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Layec, V., Institute for Information Systems University of Applied Sciences and Arts Northwestern Switzerland, FHNW, Olten, 4600, Switzerland; Wache, H., Institute for Information Systems FHNW, Olten, 4600, Switzerland
Abstract: Energy intensive industries are sensitive both to the reliability and to the costs of their energy supply system. With renewable energy becoming more affordable, their weather dependent over-and under production will cause more volatile and higher spot price, but fees prevent the roll-out of Power-To-Gas. In this paper, we differentiate the new flexible loads of energy conversion and storage like Power-To-X or batteries from the regular loads of the core activity of industries and we design the tariff system of flexible loads in such a way to be financially attractive, by abandoning a security of supply that they actually do not need. In a previous work, the technical functionality of a load management system solving the grid congestion issues was described. Here we aggregate the yearly energy balance and the associated costs in six case studies to verify that the roll-out of the new flexible loads is economically viable. The financial attractiveness of the roll-out of new flexible loads with reduced tariff system and future drop in technology price is verified in all these customers and the tariff reduction for conditional loads is the decisive factor of the profitability in four of them. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: flexible loads; power grid capacity; power tariff; security of supply; smart grid
Index Keywords: Commerce; Costs; Electric power transmission networks; Energy conversion; Energy security; Power markets; Flexible loads; Power grids; Power tariff; Security of supply; Smart grid; Smart power grids

Authors: Jereb B., Artac G.
Title: Energy Community Luče
Source title: International Conference on the European Energy Market, EEM
Affiliations: Petrol D.d, Ljubljana, Slovenia
Authors with affiliations: Jereb, B., Petrol D.d, Ljubljana, Slovenia; Artac, G., Petrol D.d, Ljubljana, Slovenia
Abstract: Process of establishing first Energy Community in Slovenia is represented in the article. Energy community will be established as a part of COMPILE project (COMPILE is cofounded by EU as part of H2020 program). Town Luče was selected as the pilot site. Members of the energy community are all connected to the transformer station Luče-Urtelj. Energy Community Luče will be completely powered from RES. To achieve the set goals additional RES (photovoltaic) and battery storage units will be installed on/in houses of members of the energy community additionally community battery will also be installed. Battery storage units in combination with comprehensive energy management will be the key elements to achieve real self-sufficiency of the energy community. Implemented measures will also demonstrate alternative ways how to provide a higher level of reliability of supply and enable additional RES penetration in weak distribution grid without classic measures for grid reinforcement-no extra overhead lines or underground cables will be implemented. Possible uses of energy community flexibility and benefits for different stakeholders (members of the energy community, DSO, TSO and aggregators) are also discussed in the article. © 2019 IEEE.

Title: Continuous full order model of triple active bridge converter
Source title: 2019 21st European Conference on Power Electronics and Applications, EPE 2019 ECCE Europe
Affiliations: TU Delft, Electrical Sustainable Energy Department, Delft, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Purgat, P., TU Delft, Electrical Sustainable Energy Department, Delft, Netherlands; Bandyopadhyay, S., TU Delft, Electrical Sustainable Energy Department, Delft, Netherlands; Qin, Z., TU Delft, Electrical Sustainable Energy Department, Delft, Netherlands; Bauer, P., TU Delft, Electrical Sustainable Energy Department, Delft, Netherlands
Abstract: With the rising popularity of the power electronic based systems with integrated energy storage, the multi-port isolated converter topologies are gaining popularity. In contemporary literature, the triple active bridge (TAB) converter is the most popular among these topologies. However, the TAB was not yet described with the continuous-time full-order model. In this paper, the continuous-time full-order model of the TAB converter is derived. The derived model is validated with the measurement of the control-to-output transfer functions. The derived model can provide useful insights into the operation of the converter and can be used for controller design. © 2019 EPE Association.
Author Keywords: Control; Dc-dc; Modelling
Index Keywords: Continuous time systems; Control engineering; Controllers; Models; Power electronics; Topology; Bridge converter; Continuous-time; Controller designs; Dc-dc; Electronic based systems; Full-order models; Integrated energy storages; Isolated converters; DC-DC converters

Authors: Zupancic J., Lakic E., Medved T., Gubina A.F.
Title: Monte carlo simulations of large-scale storage impact in distribution network
Source title: International Conference on the European Energy Market, EEM
Affiliations: University of Ljubljana, Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Laboratory for Energy Policy, Ljubljana, Slovenia
Authors with affiliations: Zupancic, J., University of Ljubljana, Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Laboratory for Energy Policy, Ljubljana, Slovenia; Lakic, E., University of Ljubljana, Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Laboratory for Energy Policy, Ljubljana, Slovenia; Medved, T., University of Ljubljana, Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Laboratory for Energy Policy, Ljubljana, Slovenia; Gubina, A.F., University of Ljubljana, Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Laboratory for Energy Policy, Ljubljana, Slovenia
Abstract: Increasing amount of decentralized renewable energy sources, transition towards smart grids and implementation of new technologies bring additional challenges in secure and stable operation of electricity network. Energy storage brings new challenges and solutions to the stable grid operation, which is affected by all new actors and technologies. Different kind of energy storage systems, which vary in scale and technology, are subject of research within EU project STORY.In addition to pilot site demonstration cases of storage implementations, one of the aims was also evaluating the impact of the storage technologies at large scale. In simulations, we performed analysis and investigate impact of the large-scale storage on the distribution network. Simulation test grid models include Medium (MV) and Low voltage (LV) networks, where urban and rural settings were considered together with industrial and residential type of end users. Grid operation was evaluated through technical parameters and Key Performance indicators (KPIs), which showed positive impact of storage technologies in smart grid transition of the power systems. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Battery energy storage system; Distribution power systems; Monte Carlo method; Renewables; Smart Grids

Authors: Weiss O., Pareschi G., Schwery O., Bolla M., Georges G., Boulouchos K.
Title: Long-Term scheduling model of Swiss hydropower
Source title: International Conference on the European Energy Market, EEM
Affiliations: ETH Zurich, Sonnegstrasse 3, Zurich, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Weiss, O., ETH Zurich, Sonnegstrasse 3, Zurich, Switzerland; Pareschi, G., ETH Zurich, Sonnegstrasse 3, Zurich, Switzerland; Schwery, O., ETH Zurich, Sonnegstrasse 3, Zurich, Switzerland; Bolla, M., ETH Zurich, Sonnegstrasse 3, Zurich, Switzerland; Georges, G., ETH Zurich, Sonnegstrasse 3, Zurich, Switzerland; Boulouchos, K., ETH Zurich, Sonnegstrasse 3, Zurich, Switzerland
Abstract: In this paper, we present a long-Term scheduling optimization model of the Swiss hydropower plants. The model considers the 68 biggest storage (SHP) and pumped hydro power plants (PHPS), covering almost 90% of the total hydropower production in Switzerland. The power plants are interconnected through rivers and water streams, consequently forming 21 independent (not exchanging water) cascades with one to five interconnected power plants in a single cascade. The modelled production of individual power plants, as well as aggregated production for the entire country, are validated against historical data. Despite the necessary assumptions made, the model provides close to reality results and can be used to model the hydro-scheduling behaviour in the future to understand the prospects and challenges of Swiss hydropower within the energy transition. © 2019 IEEE.

Authors: Akinci R., Polat M.
Title: Design and Optimization with Genetic Algorithm of Double Rotor Axial Flux Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motor (TORUS Type) for Electrical Vehicles
Source title: Proceedings - 2019 4th International Conference on Power Electronics and their Applications, ICPEA 2019
Affiliations: University of Firat, Department of Mechatronic Engineering, Elazig, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Akinci, R., University of Firat, Department of Mechatronic Engineering, Elazig, Turkey; Polat, M., University of Firat, Department of Mechatronic Engineering, Elazig, Turkey
Abstract: In recent years, interest in electric vehicles has been increasing. The most important reasons are environmental pollution caused by the density of cars in the settlement centers, the decrease in fossil fuels, the world's shortage of energy resources, advances in efficient and cost-effective electric motor and drive technology, developments in batteries that provide storage of electrical energy and driving safety come to the forefront. One of the most important factors that provide energy efficiency in electric vehicles is the motor. The axial flux permanent magnet synchronous motor, which is a dominant magnet in the field of electrical machinery in recent years, has many advantages over other types of motors. In this study, design equations of axial flux double rotor permanent magnet synchronous motor (TORUS Type) were obtained and optimization of the motor with a genetic algorithm was realized. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: axial flux permanent magnet synchronous motor; genetic algorithm; optimization; torus design

Authors: Boztas G., Aydogmus O.
Title: Design of a High-Speed PMSM for Flywheel Systems
Source title: Proceedings - 2019 4th International Conference on Power Electronics and their Applications, ICPEA 2019
Affiliations: Firat University, Department of Electrical-Electronics Enginnering, Elazig, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Boztas, G., Firat University, Department of Electrical-Electronics Enginnering, Elazig, Turkey; Aydogmus, O., Firat University, Department of Electrical-Electronics Enginnering, Elazig, Turkey
Abstract: The purpose of the current study is to obtain a motor capable of operating at high speeds up to 30,000 rpm for flywheel systems used in mechanical energy storage applications. For this purpose, a Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motor (PMSM) was designed using FEA based MAGNET program. Stator inner radius, slot depth, slot opening width, tooth tip thickness, tooth width, stack, magnet inset depth, magnet thickness, magnet angle, and number of winding turn of the motor were optimized in order to increase the motor average torque and reduce the torque ripple. The average torque was obtained as 0.5488 Nm with 19% torque ripple as a result of the design procedure. It was also analyzed in terms of the motor efficiency, flux distributions, and torque-speed curve. An inset-radial type PMSM which can be used in high-speed applications was designed as a result of the current study. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Flywheel systems; Motor Design; PMSM

Title: Measurements on encrypted and non-encrypted IoT datasets stored in relational and JSONB fields
Source title: 2019 4th South-East Europe Design Automation, Computer Engineering, Computer Networks and Social Media Conference, SEEDA-CECNSM 2019
Affiliations: University of Western Macedonia, Dept. of Business Administration, Grevena, Greece; University of Ioannina, Dept. of Mathematics, Ioannina, Greece

Abstract: Sensory data originating from IoT devices, after being received as encrypted over wireless channels, are plaintext stored in databases. However, if database data integrity, validity and safety must be ensured and additionally, IoT operations or actions implicitly require of non-repudiation, database encryption is a one-way path. Focusing on big IoT data, these encryption-decryption operations inflict database query time overheads, which in turn result in additional IoT operational delays and increased energy consumption at the wireless IoT motes. In this paper authors study the encryption performance of an open source database containing relational as well as non-relational JSONB IoT data fields and summarize their experimental results © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Database encryption; Database performance evaluation; IoT data; IoT data storage; NoSQL databases

Authors: Adrivan R.V.C., Conde R.K.G., Caberos A.B., Doloriel C.T.C.
Title: An Energy Combiner for Multi-Source Energy Harvesting with Charge Control
Source title: Proceedings - 2019 19th International Symposium on Communications and Information Technologies, ISCIT 2019
Affiliations: Mindanao State University - Iligan Institute of Technology, Microelectronics Laboratory, Iligan City, Philippines
Authors with affiliations: Adrivan, R.V.C., Mindanao State University - Iligan Institute of Technology, Microelectronics Laboratory, Iligan City, Philippines; Conde, R.K.G., Mindanao State University - Iligan Institute of Technology, Microelectronics Laboratory, Iligan City, Philippines; Caberos, A.B., Mindanao State University - Iligan Institute of Technology, Microelectronics Laboratory, Iligan City, Philippines; Doloriel, C.T.C., Mindanao State University - Iligan Institute of Technology, Microelectronics Laboratory, Iligan City, Philippines
Abstract: Presented in this paper is an energy combiner for multi-source energy harvesting implemented with charge control. The energy combiner circuit uses a voltage level detection technique with a control algorithm in combining the input energy sources and stores it in a storage battery. A charge control is implemented to prolong the life of the storage battery by limiting the minimum and maximum charge of the battery. The energy combiner achieves a combining efficiency of 94.67%, 83.11%, and 82.91% in 3 cases (a) only 1 source, (b) 2 sources and (c) 3 sources energy available, respectively. With a total power consumption of 160μW. The design was implemented in 65nm technology using Synopsys Custom Designer with an area of 160.155μm x 177.940μm. © 2019 IEEE.

Authors: Kuncoro M., Darussalam R., Sukmono C.B., Garniwa I.
Title: Dynamic power injection for solar PV constant power generation
Source title: 2019 6th International Conference on Information Technology, Computer and Electrical Engineering, ICITACEE 2019
Affiliations: University of Indonesia, Department of Electrical Engineering, Depok, Indonesia; Research Center for Electrical Power and Mechatronics, Indonesian Institute of Sciences, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Kuncoro, M., University of Indonesia, Department of Electrical Engineering, Depok, Indonesia; Darussalam, R., Research Center for Electrical Power and Mechatronics, Indonesian Institute of Sciences, Indonesia; Sukmono, C.B., University of Indonesia, Department of Electrical Engineering, Depok, Indonesia; Garniwa, I., University of Indonesia, Department of Electrical Engineering, Depok, Indonesia
Abstract: The utilization of solar energy for electricity generation is increasing. But, because of the factor of the intermittent irradiance and ambient temperature so that the energy produced fluctuates and unstable. For PV connected to the grid, these power fluctuations affect system stability and frequency. To overcome this problem, several methods for PV power stabilization have been developed. One of them is the Constant Power Generation, where PV output power is limited to a certain power value so it can reduce PV power fluctuations. In this paper, the Dynamic Power Injection method is proposed as modification of the CPG method with energy storage batteries. In principle DPI similar with the CPG method that determines the power limit, but DPI operation include the active power management by charging and discharging action. The battery is using as energy storage when Power PV greater Power limit. On the other hand battery as an energy source for active power injection at Power PV less than Power limit. Thus the output power in each condition can be maintained as Power PV equal with P limit. In this research, DPI modules are built on Arduino controller-based and monitored with the thingspeak webserver. The experimental results of DPI can stabilize PV power fluctuation at it's setting power with an error of 5% and a 15-second time delay. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: CPG; DPI; Stabilization; Thingspeak
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Solar energy; Stabilization; System stability; Constant power; Dynamic Power; Electricity generation; Energy source; Power fluctuations; Power stabilization; Storage battery; Thingspeak; Secondary batteries

Authors: Ahmed K.M.U., Sutaria J., Bollen M.H.J., Rönnberg S.K.
Title: Electrical Energy Consumption Model of Internal Components in Data Centers
Source title: Proceedings of 2019 IEEE PES Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Europe, ISGT-Europe 2019
Affiliations: Luleå University of Technology, Electric Power Engineering, Skellefteå, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Ahmed, K.M.U., Luleå University of Technology, Electric Power Engineering, Skellefteå, Sweden; Sutaria, J., Luleå University of Technology, Electric Power Engineering, Skellefteå, Sweden; Bollen, M.H.J., Luleå University of Technology, Electric Power Engineering, Skellefteå, Sweden; Rönnberg, S.K., Luleå University of Technology, Electric Power Engineering, Skellefteå, Sweden
Abstract: In the context of modern information technology (IT) industry, cloud computing is gaining popularity for big data handling. Therefore, IT service providers like Google, Facebook and Amazon are expanding their technical resources by building data centers to improve the data processing and data storage facilities under cloud service pattern. However, data centers consume a large amount of electrical energy. In recent years, a lot of research has been done to reduce the electrical energy consumption of data centers by high performance computing. However, very few researchers have focused on the electrical energy consumption by the electrical components inside the data center. In this paper, a component based electrical energy consumption modelling approach is presented to identify the losses of different components as well as their interactions to the total electrical energy consumption of the data center. The electrical energy consumption models of servers and other components are presented as a function of server utilization. © 2019 IEEE.
