Authors: Sai L., Liu C., Lu F., Sai T.
Title: A reconstructing method of PSWF pulse based on three-valued Walsh interpolation functions
Source title: Proceedings of 2019 IEEE 3rd Information Technology, Networking, Electronic and Automation Control Conference, ITNEC 2019
Affiliations: Naval Aviation University, Shandong, China; Zhejiang University, Zhejiang, China
Authors with affiliations: Sai, L., Naval Aviation University, Shandong, China; Liu, C., Naval Aviation University, Shandong, China; Lu, F., Naval Aviation University, Shandong, China; Sai, T., Zhejiang University, Zhejiang, China
Abstract: Aiming at the problems that currently obtaining prolate spheroidal wave functions (PSWF) is large amount of computation, poor real-time performance, high hardware cost, and low storage efficiency, this paper first studies the reconstructing method of PSWF pulse based on Walsh function system. Secondly, using Walsh function interpolation theory and generalized Walsh function system theory, a reconstruction method of PSWF pulse based on three-valued Walsh interpolation functions is proposed. Finally, through theoretical analysis and simulation, it is considered that comparing with the reconstructing method based on Walsh function system, using this paper's method can achieve more ideal reconstruction results, although it will pay a small increase in the computational cost. The ideal reconstruction results mainly reflected in: the accuracy of the reconstructed signal is higher, the pulse waveform is relatively smooth, the orthogonality between the reconstructed pulses is more stable, and the frequency domain energy concentration of the reconstructed signal is substantially the same as the original signal. This method provides an effective theoretical reference for the hardware design of PSWF pulse real-time generation. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Cyclic shift copy theory; PSWF; Three-valued Walsh interpolation functions
Index Keywords: Computation theory; Cost benefit analysis; Frequency domain analysis; Interpolation; Walsh transforms; Wave functions; Analysis and simulation; Cyclic shifts; Energy concentration; Interpolation function; Prolate spheroidal wave functions; PSWF; Real time performance; Reconstruction method; Signal reconstruction

Authors: Dobrin I., Enache D., Dumitru G., Dobrin A., Popovici I., Pintea R.
Title: Design and Modeling of a Persistent Switch of HTS Coils for a Magnetic Energy Storage System
Source title: 2019 11th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering, ATEE 2019
Affiliations: National Institute for Research and Development in Electrical Engineering, ICPE - CA, Bucharest, Romania
Authors with affiliations: Dobrin, I., National Institute for Research and Development in Electrical Engineering, ICPE - CA, Bucharest, Romania; Enache, D., National Institute for Research and Development in Electrical Engineering, ICPE - CA, Bucharest, Romania; Dumitru, G., National Institute for Research and Development in Electrical Engineering, ICPE - CA, Bucharest, Romania; Dobrin, A., National Institute for Research and Development in Electrical Engineering, ICPE - CA, Bucharest, Romania; Popovici, I., National Institute for Research and Development in Electrical Engineering, ICPE - CA, Bucharest, Romania; Pintea, R., National Institute for Research and Development in Electrical Engineering, ICPE - CA, Bucharest, Romania
Abstract: A high temperature superconducting (HTS) material like YBCO type, of second generation (2G) coated conductor, was chosen for the execution of the superconducting coils which are part of a superconducting magnetic energy storage system (SMES) under construction in ICPE-CA. A very important issue for a superconducting magnetic energy storage system is the persistent mode operation of the HTS coils together with the junctions resistivity. The switch between "persistent mode" and "driven mode" operation of a superconducting coil is performed by the so called "persistent switch" (PS). This paper describes the design and the numerical modeling of a PS meant to work with the HTS coils, and some experimental results regarding the physical properties of the YBCO tape, necessary for the design of the PS. The numerical modeling results refers to magnetic field generated by the coils and the thermal behavior of the PS. The Comsol Multiphysics software was used to obtain the numerical results. © 2019 IEEE.

Authors: Grigoras G., Neagu B.-C., Ivanov O.
Title: Aggregate Method based on Expert System for Electricity Consumption Forecasting of Small and Medium Enterprises
Source title: 2019 11th International Symposium on Advanced Topics in Electrical Engineering, ATEE 2019
Affiliations: Gheorghe Asachi Technical University of Iasi, Romania
Authors with affiliations: Grigoras, G., Gheorghe Asachi Technical University of Iasi, Romania; Neagu, B.-C., Gheorghe Asachi Technical University of Iasi, Romania; Ivanov, O., Gheorghe Asachi Technical University of Iasi, Romania
Abstract: The decisions making process for energy efficiency improvement based on technological activities and flows reconfiguration at Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) requires a better understanding of the electricity consumption characteristics, and its share on each equipment/installation. In the paper, an expert system-based aggregate method is proposed for electricity consumption forecasting at SMEs. The proposed method was tested at an industrial consumer (a small enterprise in the automobile repair activity domain). The obtained results led at smaller forecasting errors with the average error in the analysed period (a week) by 2.45 %. © 2019 IEEE.

Authors: Sterling G., Tyler B.
Title: Renewable Energy Management Using Action Dependent Heuristic Dynamic Programming
Source title: 2018 IEEE International Smart Cities Conference, ISC2 2018
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, Nazarbayev University, Astana, Kazakhstan
Authors with affiliations: Sterling, G., Department of Computer Science, Nazarbayev University, Astana, Kazakhstan; Tyler, B., Department of Computer Science, Nazarbayev University, Astana, Kazakhstan
Abstract: With increases in global energy demand and the rapid consumption of fossil fuels, the use of green energy and more efficient energy management approaches are receiving serious attention. Our focus is on improving energy resource scheduling in smart buildings and homes to minimize cost, while meeting energy demand. Here, we present an approach using Action Dependent Heuristic Dynamic Programming (ADHDP) optimization for a smart home set-up using solar panels, wind turbines, and a storage battery.In this work, we trained and evaluated our ADHDP approach using different simulation scenarios with various amounts of available renewable energy. We then demonstrated via computer simulation that our approach is more effective in cost minimization compared to a standard rule-based method. A correlation between optimization improvement and available renewable energy was also confirmed by computer simulation in all scenarios. © 2018 IEEE.

Title: Development of Low Power Full-Custom 1 Kb 8T Synchronous SRAM for Wireless Sensor Network in 90nm CMOS Process Technology
Source title: IEEE Region 10 Annual International Conference, Proceedings/TENCON
Affiliations: College of Engineering, First Asia Institute of Technology and Humanities, Tanauan City, Batangas, Philippines
Authors with affiliations: Jacinto, S.A.D.V., College of Engineering, First Asia Institute of Technology and Humanities, Tanauan City, Batangas, Philippines; Nanoz, A.J.M., College of Engineering, First Asia Institute of Technology and Humanities, Tanauan City, Batangas, Philippines; Punzalan, J.R.A., College of Engineering, First Asia Institute of Technology and Humanities, Tanauan City, Batangas, Philippines; Malabanan, F.A., College of Engineering, First Asia Institute of Technology and Humanities, Tanauan City, Batangas, Philippines; Santos, A.S., College of Engineering, First Asia Institute of Technology and Humanities, Tanauan City, Batangas, Philippines; Tabing, J.N.T., College of Engineering, First Asia Institute of Technology and Humanities, Tanauan City, Batangas, Philippines; Gevana, S.M., College of Engineering, First Asia Institute of Technology and Humanities, Tanauan City, Batangas, Philippines
Abstract: The aftermath of endless environmental degradation poses a lot of risk among individuals including climate change. Modern technology addresses the need of a more competent environmental monitoring through Internet of Things (IoT) and the use of System-on-Chips (SoCs) such as Environmental Sensor Platform. One of the critical components of SoC is a Random Access Memory (RAM) which presents a sizable fraction of power consumption. This makes memory inappropriate for energy-constrained applications such as environmental monitoring. The purpose of this study is the development of low power full-custom 8T SRAM for sensor platforms. Different SRAM topologies were evaluated to identify which among has the lowest power consumption. Verified through simulations, a fully functioning schematic that can read and write data were designed in 90nm CMOS process technology. Layout of each block were created using Synopsys design tools yielding power consumption of 21.0405mW and static noise margin of 520mV achieved by eliminating sense amplifier and pre-charge circuits. This study significantly reduced power consumption of memory which is suitable for environmental monitoring applications. © 2018 IEEE.

Authors: Domingo A.J., Carlo Garcia F., Salvana M.L., Libatique D.N.J.C., Tangonan D.G.L.
Title: Short Term Wind Speed Forecasting : A Machine Learning Based Predictive Analytics
Source title: IEEE Region 10 Annual International Conference, Proceedings/TENCON
Affiliations: Electronics, Computer and Communications Engineering Department, Ateneo de Manila University, Quezon City, 1108, Philippines; King Abdullah University of Science and Technology, Ateneo de Manila University, Quezon City, 1108, Philippines; Ateneo Innovation Center, Ateneo de Manila University, Quezon City, 1108, Philippines
Authors with affiliations: Domingo, A.J., Electronics, Computer and Communications Engineering Department, Ateneo de Manila University, Quezon City, 1108, Philippines; Carlo Garcia, F., Electronics, Computer and Communications Engineering Department, Ateneo de Manila University, Quezon City, 1108, Philippines; Salvana, M.L., King Abdullah University of Science and Technology, Ateneo de Manila University, Quezon City, 1108, Philippines; Libatique, D.N.J.C., Electronics, Computer and Communications Engineering Department, Ateneo de Manila University, Quezon City, 1108, Philippines; Tangonan, D.G.L., Ateneo Innovation Center, Ateneo de Manila University, Quezon City, 1108, Philippines
Abstract: The challenges posed by the intermittence and uncertainty of renewable energy due to its variability and limited storage require accurate forecasts for economies looking to source a significant amount of energy from renewables. We report on the use of several supervised learning models such as Random Forest, Extremely Randomized Trees, Support Vector Regression and k-Nearest Neighbors Regression to forecast ahead of time wind speed measurements using data from the wind met masts located at Buguey, Ballesteros and Sta. Ana, Cagayan. Results show that in terms of predicting the next hour wind speed measurements for one day, the k-NNR model outperforms the other three models while the ET model have shown the highest predictive performance among the four models in prediction of the next hour wind speed measurements for one month and 20% of the total data. It is anticipated that the proposed ET model can be used as an effective wind speed prediction model as well as the k-NNR model. The common perception by energy companies in ASEAN that RE output is unpredictable needs to be rethought in the sight of the new AI techniques. © 2018 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Extremely Randomized Trees; k-Nearest Neighbors; Random Forest; Renewable Energy; Support Vector Regression; Wind Power Forecasting

Authors: Kong Y., Zhang Y., Wang Y., Chen H., Hei X.
Title: Energy saving strategy for task migration based on genetic algorithm
Source title: Proceedings - 2018 International Conference on Networking and Network Applications, NaNA 2018
Affiliations: Xi'an University of Technology, School of Computer Science and Engineering, Xi'an, 710048, China
Authors with affiliations: Kong, Y., Xi'an University of Technology, School of Computer Science and Engineering, Xi'an, 710048, China; Zhang, Y., Xi'an University of Technology, School of Computer Science and Engineering, Xi'an, 710048, China; Wang, Y., Xi'an University of Technology, School of Computer Science and Engineering, Xi'an, 710048, China; Chen, H., Xi'an University of Technology, School of Computer Science and Engineering, Xi'an, 710048, China; Hei, X., Xi'an University of Technology, School of Computer Science and Engineering, Xi'an, 710048, China
Abstract: With the rapid development and popularization of mobile Internet and Internet of Things, People have entered the era of Internet of Everything. Mobile edge computing is the key technology to improving the user experience of 5G network in the future, which is close to the data source, so that it can effectively reduce the network transmission delay. Edge computing will sink the business to the edge of the network, provide computing services and storage services, and provide task migration platform for users. At present, the current battery development speed of mobile devices is far behind the development speed of its processor and memory. Therefore, to solve the problem of 'how to realize the low energy migration of complex dependency application', a fine-grained directed acyclic graph task partition model is established based on the characteristics of mobile edge computing, and the relationships among the divided subtasks are analyzed to construct the minimization energy consumption problem under the execution time limit, then uses the genetic algorithm to find the optimal solution, and obtains the result of the migration decision for each sub task, that is, the optimal energy-saving migration plan for the entire mobile terminal application. The experimental results show that the fine-grained task migration strategy proposed in this paper makes full use of the advantages of mobile edge computing, and can effectively reduce the energy consumption of mobile terminal devices on the premise of meeting the task execution delay. © 2018 IEEE.
Author Keywords: 5G; Energy saving; Internet of Things; Mobile edge computing; Task migration
Index Keywords: Computer terminals; Digital storage; Directed graphs; Edge computing; Energy conservation; Energy utilization; Genetic algorithms; Green computing; Internet of things; Mobile telecommunication systems; Battery development; Computing services; Directed acyclic graph (DAG); Energy-saving strategies; Minimization energies; Network transmission delays; Optimal solutions; Task migration; 5G mobile communication systems

Authors: Samuel O., Khan Z.A., Iqbal S., Javaid N.
Title: An Efficient Energy Management in Micro grid: A Game Theoretic Approach
Source title: ITT 2018 - Information Technology Trends: Emerging Technologies for Artificial Intelligence
Affiliations: COMSATS University Islamabad, Islamabad, 44000, Pakistan; Computer Information Science, Higher Colleges of Technology, Fujairah, United Arab Emirates; National University Os Science and Technology, Islamabad, 44000, Pakistan
Authors with affiliations: Samuel, O., COMSATS University Islamabad, Islamabad, 44000, Pakistan; Khan, Z.A., Computer Information Science, Higher Colleges of Technology, Fujairah, United Arab Emirates; Iqbal, S., National University Os Science and Technology, Islamabad, 44000, Pakistan; Javaid, N., COMSATS University Islamabad, Islamabad, 44000, Pakistan
Abstract: Presently, power systems have the capacities to accommodate different framework for incorporating economic dispatch, transmission, storage, and electricity consumption. This can provide an efficient energy management for controlling, coordinating, planning and operations. This paper focuses on coordinating the behaviors of a typical energy management of microgrid which is an issue on energy interconnections. A setup of microgrid, electricity users, storage and utility company is designed. Initially, optimal solution is formulated as a three stage Stackelberg game in which each player is allow to maximize its payoffs, while ensuring load stability and reliability. The method of backward induction is applied to examine the non cooperative game problem. We further proposed an efficient Jaya-based conditional restricted Boltzmann machine for microgrid power output forecasting which enable the microgrid make strategic decision. Simulation results validate the fact that accurate prediction of renewable energy can influence the choice of microgrid strategies. © 2018 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Energy management; Load forecasting; Stackelberg game
Index Keywords: Electric power system economics; Electric power transmission; Energy efficiency; Energy management; Forecasting; Game theory; Scheduling; Accurate prediction; Conditional restricted boltzmann machines; Electricity-consumption; Load forecasting; Noncooperative game; Renewable energies; Stackelberg Games; Strategic decisions; Electric load dispatching

Authors: Beccaria E., Bogado V., Palombarini J.A.
Title: A DEVS-based Simulation Model for Biogas Generation for Electrical Energy Production
Source title: 2018 IEEE Biennial Congress of Argentina, ARGENCON 2018
Affiliations: Departamento Ingenieria en Sistemas de Informacion, UTN FRVM, Av. Universidad 450, Villa Maria, Cordoba, X5900 HLR, Argentina; CIT Villa Maria (CONICET-UNVM), Carlos Pellegrini, 211, Villa Maria, Cordoba, Argentina

Universidad 450, Villa Maria, Cordoba, X5900 HLR, Argentina, CIT Villa Maria (CONICET-UNVM), Carlos Pellegrini, 211, Villa Maria, Cordoba, Argentina; Palombarini, J.A., Departamento Ingenieria en Sistemas de Informacion, UTN FRVM, Av. Universidad 450, Villa Maria, Cordoba, X5900 HLR, Argentina, CIT Villa Maria (CONICET-UNVM), Carlos Pellegrini, 211, Villa Maria, Cordoba, Argentina
Abstract: Renewable energies have a significant role to solve the energy problems in a substantial way in the years to come. In this context, an integral preventive planning regarding the generation and use of different types of renewable energy in environments with variable energy consumption requirements is necessary. This work presents a model based on Discrete Event System Specification (DEVS) to simulate the generation and storage of biogas produced from organic waste. Furthermore, the use of the generated biogas to produce electrical energy in a supply and demand environment is also addressed with the aim of validating different scenarios of generation and consumption and allowing a better decision-making process to improve the production and use of biogas. Finally, the achieved results show that the approach is able to provide a reliable way to analyze the biogas production and consumption process with respect to several significant process variables. In addition, the proposed model could be implemented to control the operation and planning of biogas production without relying on computationally intensive mathematical optimization models. © 2018 IEEE.

Authors with affiliations: Carlucho, I., Rupo INTELYMEC, Centro de Investigaciones en Fisica e Ingenieria Del Centro (CIFICEN-CONICET- CICpBA), Fac. de Ingenieria, Universidad Nacional Del Centro de la Prov. de Buenos Aires (UNCPBA), Olavarria, B7400JWI, Argentina; De La Vega, R., Rupo INTELYMEC, Centro de Investigaciones en Fisica e Ingenieria Del Centro (CIFICEN-CONICET- CICpBA), Fac. de Ingenieria, Universidad Nacional Del Centro de la Prov. de Buenos Aires (UNCPBA), Olavarria, B7400JWI, Argentina; Spina, M., Rupo INTELYMEC, Centro de Investigaciones en Fisica e Ingenieria Del Centro (CIFICEN-CONICET- CICpBA), Fac. de Ingenieria, Universidad Nacional Del Centro de la Prov. de Buenos Aires (UNCPBA), Olavarria, B7400JWI, Argentina; Acosta, G.G., Rupo INTELYMEC, Centro de Investigaciones en Fisica e Ingenieria Del Centro (CIFICEN-CONICET- CICpBA), Fac. de Ingenieria, Universidad Nacional Del Centro de la Prov. de Buenos Aires (UNCPBA), Olavarria, B7400JWI, Argentina
Abstract: In electric vehicles the energy storage provided by the batteries is of utmost importance: it provides autonomy to the vehicle. However rechargeable batteries cannot operate alone, a Battery Management System is needed to provide safe operation conditions, monitor its state and balance its charge. In this article a Battery Management System is developed for applications in electric vehicles and autonomous robotics. We design the system in a modular way to give flexibility and allow portability to different type of battery packs. Low-cost microcontrollers were used for the system providing also communication with the vechicle's on-board computer. A passive balancing schemed is chosen as a way of battery balancing. The proposed system was tested using a battery pack demonstrating its balancing capabilities. © 2018 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Autonomous vehicles; Battery Pack; Electric vehicles; Autonomous robotics; Low costs; Onboard computers; Safe operation; Battery management systems

Authors: Salama H.S., Aly M.M., Vokony I.
Title: Voltage/Frequency Control of Isolated Unbalanced Radial Distribution System Fed from Intermittent Wind/PV Power Using Fuzzy Logic Controlled-SMES
Source title: Proceedings of 2019 International Conference on Innovative Trends in Computer Engineering, ITCE 2019
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Aswan University, Aswan, 81542, Egypt; Department of Electric Power Engineering, Budapest University of Technology and Economics, Budapest, Hungary
Authors with affiliations: Salama, H.S., Department of Electrical Engineering, Aswan University, Aswan, 81542, Egypt, Department of Electric Power Engineering, Budapest University of Technology and Economics, Budapest, Hungary; Aly, M.M., Department of Electrical Engineering, Aswan University, Aswan, 81542, Egypt; Vokony, I., Department of Electric Power Engineering, Budapest University of Technology and Economics, Budapest, Hungary
Abstract: Nowadays, the world is directing to the renewable energy sources to generate electricity. However, these sources have Intermittent energy nature which leads to fluctuations in the voltage and frequency, so it became necessary to use controlled energy storage units. This paper addresses an isolated unbalanced three-phase radial distribution system fed from wind energy conversion system (WECS) of squirrel cage induction generator (SCIG) and photovoltaic (PV) power for energy injection. Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) units have been used as energy storage system to mitigate the intermittent power generated from renewable energy sources. Fuzzy logic controller is used to control the charging/discharging of SMES. MATLAB/Simulink package is used to demonstrate the system, WECS, PV, and SMES. The simulated results illustrated the ability the fuzzy logic controlled-SMES to mitigate the intermittency of power generated from WECS/PV that helps to control the frequency and voltage of the studied system. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Fuzzy logic controller (FLC); Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES); Unbalanced distribution system; Wind/PV power

Authors: Stoev P., Angelov I., Matanov N.
Title: Dimming Control of LED Lighting Fixtures Powered with Photovoltaic Modules
Source title: 2018 10th Electrical Engineering Faculty Conference, BulEF 2018
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Power Supply, Electrical Equipment and Electrical Transport, Technical University of Sofia, Sofia, Bulgaria
Authors with affiliations: Stoev, P., Department of Electrical Power Supply, Electrical Equipment and Electrical Transport, Technical University of Sofia, Sofia, Bulgaria; Angelov, I., Department of Electrical Power Supply, Electrical Equipment and Electrical Transport, Technical University of Sofia, Sofia, Bulgaria; Matanov, N., Department of Electrical Power Supply, Electrical Equipment and Electrical Transport, Technical University of Sofia, Sofia, Bulgaria
Abstract: This paper presents the operation of lighting control system with LED luminaires. A lighting system primarily powered by Photovoltaic panels has been studied and in order to ensure uninterrupted operation, has been reserved by the LV electrical network. Such a system can be used in tunnel lighting systems to power part of the adaptation and / or permanent lighting system. Both lighting systems work during the day, with the overall adaptation brightness being greatest during the interval 11am - 2pm when the PV string power generated reaches its peak. In order to achieve more significant economic effect, neither energy storage elements, nor maximum power point tracking controller have been added. The principle of control on the luminaires has been presented according to the photovoltaic plant output voltage variation. A simulation model has been developed in Matlab aiming to simulate and analyze the system's performance. The system's characteristic have been presented for the entire range of photovoltaics operation. © 2018 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Dimming control; Led lighting; Photovoltaic module

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems - ICPADS
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Parallel and Distributed Systems - ICPADS
Abstract: The proceedings contain 137 papers. The topics discussed include: CoLoR: co-located rescuers for fault tolerance in HPC systems; estimating the extrema of large-scale RFID systems; optimizing deep learning frameworks incrementally to get linear speedup: a comparison between IPoIB and RDMA verbs; exploiting code diversity to enhance code virtualization protection; effectiveness of moldable and malleable scheduling in deep learning tasks; energy-efficient core allocation and deployment for container-based virtualization; topology-aware efficient storage scheme for fault-tolerant storage systems in data centers; mobility-driven BLE transmit-power adaptation for participatory data muling; and SRVoice: a robust sparse representation-based liveness detection system.

Authors: Guangul F.M., Chala G.T.
Title: Solar energy as renewable energy source: SWOT analysis
Source title: 2019 4th MEC International Conference on Big Data and Smart City, ICBDSC 2019
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Middle East College, Muscat, Oman; Department of Mechanical Engineering, International College of Engineering and Management, Muscat, Oman
Authors with affiliations: Guangul, F.M., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Middle East College, Muscat, Oman; Chala, G.T., Department of Mechanical Engineering, International College of Engineering and Management, Muscat, Oman
Abstract: The adverse environmental effects from fossil fuels and their depletion through time push the world to consider sustainable and environmentally friendly forms of energy sources. The advancement put forward to improve the performance of Solar energy has made it to be one of the potential alternative energy sources in the years ahead. This paper, therefore, assesses the strength, weakness, opportunities and threats (SWOT) of using solar energy. The suitability of solar energy to the environment, minimal cost in the long ran, and its versatility are few to mention among other significant advantages of this energy source to get noticeable attention in an effort to substitute fossil fuels. The expected cost reduction through time with the technology advancement is also taken as opportunity to use solar energy. However, using solar energy has also weaknesses and threats which yet require further attentions. The low efficiency, high initial cost, energy storage requirement are some of the challenges. In addition, shifting the energy source for industries from fossil fuel to solar energy remains as a challenge due to the utilities which are already in place and working with conventional fuels. Although some of the weaknesses and threats to solar energy application still exist, through technology advancement most of the problems would be addressed in the future. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Fossil fuels; Renewable energy; Solar energy; SWOT analysis
Index Keywords: Big data; Cost reduction; Digital storage; Fossil fuels; Smart city; Alternative energy source; Opportunities and threat (SWOT); Renewable energies; Renewable energy source; Solar energy applications; Storage requirements; SWOT analysis; Technology advancement; Solar energy

Authors: Jafari A., Hosseini M., Homayoun H., Mohsenin T.
Title: A scalable and low power DCNN for multimodal data classification
Source title: 2018 International Conference on Reconfigurable Computing and FPGAs, ReConFig 2018
Authors with affiliations: Jafari, A.; Hosseini, M.; Homayoun, H.; Mohsenin, T.
Abstract: This paper presents SensorNet which is a scalable and low power embedded Deep Convolutional Neural Network (DCNN), designed to classify multimodal time series signals. Time series signals generated by different sensor modalities with different sampling rates are first converted to images (2-D signals) and then DCNN is utilized to automatically learn shared features in the images and perform the classification. SensorNet is scalable with respect to different types of multi-channel time series data, and does not require expert knowledge for extracting features for each sensor data. Additionally, it can achieve very high detection accuracy for different case studies, and has a very efficient architecture which makes it suitable to be employed at IoT and wearable devices. A custom low power hardware architecture is also designed for the efficient deployment of SensorNet at embedded real-time systems. SensorNet performance is evaluated using three different case studies including Physical Activity Monitoring, stand-alone Tongue Drive System (sdTDS) and Stress Detection and it achieves an average detection accuracy of 98%, 96.2% and 94% for each case study, respectively. We implement SensorNet using our custom hardware architecture on Xilinx FPGA (Artix-7) which on average consumes 0.3 mJ energy per classification while meeting all applications time requirements. To further reduce the power consumption, SensorNet is implemented using ASIC at the post layout level in 65-nm CMOS technology which consumes approximately 8 × lower power compared to the FPGA. © 2018 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Deep neural networks; Digital storage; Embedded systems; Field programmable gate arrays (FPGA); Interactive computer systems; Low power electronics; Network architecture; Neural networks; Reconfigurable architectures; Reconfigurable hardware; Time series; Convolutional neural network; Detection accuracy; Efficient architecture; Embedded real time systems; Extracting features; Physical activity monitoring; Time requirements; Time series signals; Real time systems

Authors: Cheng S., Zhou Y., Li Q.
Title: Polymer-based dielectric materials for high-temperature film capacitors
Source title: ICHVE 2018 - 2018 IEEE International Conference on High Voltage Engineering and Application
Affiliations: State Key Lab of Power Systems, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China
Authors with affiliations: Cheng, S., State Key Lab of Power Systems, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China; Zhou, Y., State Key Lab of Power Systems, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China; Li, Q., State Key Lab of Power Systems, Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China
Abstract: High-temperature dielectrics capacitors are highly needed in the electrical and electronic industries, underground oil explorations and many other areas. However, the apparent conductions loss under high temperatures and the related thermal runaway are the main problems with the high-temperature polymer dielectric. In this report, we summarized and presented three recently developed approaches to improve the energy-storage properties by suppressing the conduction loss under high temperatures. The three approaches include single-layer nanocomposites with highly insulated inorganic nanosheets, sandwich-structured composites and inorganic-coated polymers. All the three approaches can effectively decrease the leakage current and improve the discharged energy density. © 2018 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Polymers; Conduction loss; Discharged energy densities; Electronic industries; Energy storage properties; High temperature; High temperature polymers; Oil exploration; Thermal runaways; Dielectric materials

Authors: Tsikimis B.S., Chardalias T.Ch., Ftoulis A.K., Koutsoubis J.M., Manasis Ch.X.
Title: A Fast, High-Voltage, Pulse Power Driving Circuit for Copper-Halide Lasers
Source title: ICHVE 2018 - 2018 IEEE International Conference on High Voltage Engineering and Application
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Technological Educational Institute (TEI) of Sterea Ellada, Euboea, Psahna GR, 34400, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Tsikimis, B.S., Department of Electrical Engineering, Technological Educational Institute (TEI) of Sterea Ellada, Euboea, Psahna GR, 34400, Greece; Chardalias, T.Ch., Department of Electrical Engineering, Technological Educational Institute (TEI) of Sterea Ellada, Euboea, Psahna GR, 34400, Greece; Ftoulis, A.K., Department of Electrical Engineering, Technological Educational Institute (TEI) of Sterea Ellada, Euboea, Psahna GR, 34400, Greece; Koutsoubis, J.M., Department of Electrical Engineering, Technological Educational Institute (TEI) of Sterea Ellada, Euboea, Psahna GR, 34400, Greece; Manasis, Ch.X., Department of Electrical Engineering, Technological Educational Institute (TEI) of Sterea Ellada, Euboea, Psahna GR, 34400, Greece
Abstract: Copper vapor lasers as well as its various types are extendedly studied over the last fifty years due to their wide use. Among these types, the copper-halide laser is by far the more commonly used today, due to its much lower discharge tube operating temperature and less stringent driving circuit requirements. A fast, high-voltage pulsed power circuit has been developed for driving copper halide lasers. This circuit utilizes the principle of the resonant charging of a load capacitor from a storage capacitor by means of a charging inductor, a technique which offers a more efficient transfer of energy and a higher output voltage magnitude than resistive charging. In order to operate the laser driving circuit at high-voltage, fast pulse rise time and high-repetition rate requirements, a hydrogen thyratron was employed as a switching device. The circuit is capable of producing output voltage pulses in excess of 10kV, with a rise time and duration of 30ns and 70ns (Full Width at Half Magnitude-FWHM) respectively, and is fully controlled from single shot up to a maximum pulse repetition frequency (PRF) of 150Hz. © 2018 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Copper halide lasers; pulsed power; resonant charging; thyratron plasma closing switches

Authors: Huang B., Li X., Li D.
Title: Green virtualized edge computing: Successive Cournot model analysis
Source title: AIP Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Department of Communication Engineering, Nanjing University of Posts and Telecomm, Nanjing, 210003, China; Nanjing University of Posts and Telecomm, Nanjing, 210003, China
Authors with affiliations: Huang, B., Department of Communication Engineering, Nanjing University of Posts and Telecomm, Nanjing, 210003, China; Li, X., Nanjing University of Posts and Telecomm, Nanjing, 210003, China; Li, D., Department of Communication Engineering, Nanjing University of Posts and Telecomm, Nanjing, 210003, China
Abstract: With the rapid development of mobile smart devices, there are increasing number of data traffic which will consume large amounts of energy. In this paper, we investigate a renewable energy allocation scheme in a multi-node edge-computing system. Specifically, several renewable power suppliers (RPSs) cooperate with each other to provide each node with green energy resources to the base station (BS) in the backhaul are considered. These RPSs supplying energy to each backhaul node have a complementary relationship, and the game between them is modeled as »successive Coordinated Cournot». Assuming that the RPSs offer undifferentiated renewable energy and, the energy storage are produced in the fixed proportions, the equilibrium prices for the whole system are characterized by a system of linear equations. The theoretical analysis and simulation results show that the proposed pricing scheme can increase the profits of the RPSs. In addition, the factors that influence the equilibrium selling prices and profits are studied, and the simulation results show how the quantity of RPSs influences the equilibrium price and the renewable energy production capacity. © 2019 Author(s).
Author Keywords: Edge-computing; Equilibrium Pricing; Game Theory; Renewable Energy

Authors: Haine T., Flandre D., Bol D.
Title: 8-T ULV SRAM macro in 28nm FDSOI with 7.4 pW/bit retention power and back-biased-scalable speed/energy trade-off
Source title: 2018 IEEE SOI-3D-Subthreshold Microelectronics Technology Unified Conference, S3S 2018
Affiliations: Electronic Circuits and Systems (ECS), ICTEAM Institute, Université catholique de Louvain, Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Haine, T., Electronic Circuits and Systems (ECS), ICTEAM Institute, Université catholique de Louvain, Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium; Flandre, D., Electronic Circuits and Systems (ECS), ICTEAM Institute, Université catholique de Louvain, Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium; Bol, D., Electronic Circuits and Systems (ECS), ICTEAM Institute, Université catholique de Louvain, Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium
Abstract: In this paper, we propose an ultra-low-voltage SRAM macro in 28nm FDSOI based on an 8-T ULP bitcell. Data retention in the proposed bitcell is obtained with two CMOS negative-differential resistance structures, which allow for using only low-Vt transistors for density and speed without prohibitive leakage. The bitcell was sized to reach low failure rate for 32-kB macro with a gradient-based importance sampling methodology. Thanks to the exclusive use of low-Vt transistors, adaptive back biasing allows for compensating PVT variations as well as scaling the power/performance trade-off. At 0.55V, the proposed SRAM can operate at up to 200 MHz and reaches an average access energy of 20.4 fJ/bit. In sleep mode with data retention, the leakage power goes down to 7.4 pW/bit. © 2018 IEEE.

Authors: Savić N.S., Katić V.A., Katić N.A., Dumnić B., Milićević D., Čorba Z.
Title: Techno-economic and environmental analysis of a microgrid concept in the university campus
Source title: 2018 International Symposium on Industrial Electronics, INDEL 2018 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Faculty of Technical Sciences, University of Novi Sad, Novi Sad, Serbia
Authors with affiliations: Savić, N.S., Faculty of Technical Sciences, University of Novi Sad, Novi Sad, Serbia; Katić, V.A., Faculty of Technical Sciences, University of Novi Sad, Novi Sad, Serbia; Katić, N.A., Faculty of Technical Sciences, University of Novi Sad, Novi Sad, Serbia; Dumnić, B., Faculty of Technical Sciences, University of Novi Sad, Novi Sad, Serbia; Milićević, D., Faculty of Technical Sciences, University of Novi Sad, Novi Sad, Serbia; Čorba, Z., Faculty of Technical Sciences, University of Novi Sad, Novi Sad, Serbia
Abstract: Following the latest trends in the research, development and promotion of clean energy technologies in order to solve serious problems of increased electricity consumption, greenhouse gases emissions, global warming and climate change, the Faculty of Technical Sciences in Novi Sad has designed the concept of microgrid based on application of different types of distributed energy resources. This paper presents the concept of the idea project of a faculty microgrid consisting of 2 photovoltaic power plants, 2 wind turbines, biogas microturbine for combined heat and power production, 2 electric vehicles as prosumers, battery energy storage system, microgrid microcontroller, interface for connecting the microgrid to the main distribution grid, and electricity consumers. In order to enable and ensure the stable operation of the microgrid in the island mode, the technical specifications of the energy devices, control devices and measuring equipment that have been installed and planned are also analyzed and presented. The paper presents a techno-economic and environmental analysis of the application of the faculty microgrid, with a special focus on the annual energy production, investment costs and avoided CO2 emissions realized through the use of proposed distributed energy sources. © 2018 IEEE.

Box 12363, Jacobs, Durban, 4026, South Africa
Abstract: In this paper, an optimal energy control model is used to evaluate the potential energy cost saving of a hybrid solar water heater. The aim is to maximize energy cost savings under time-based pricing while maintaining the desired water temperature of the hot water user. The optimally controlled system is compared to traditional timer based controlled system with the same layout as the proposed system. The hybrid water heating system is modelled and simulated using Matlab. From the formulated objective function and the case study in this work, the results present that using an optimally controlled hybrid heater will have an approximate annual cost saving of 20.8%. © 2018 Cape Peninsula University of technology.

Title: Advanced control scheme for bidirectional grid-connected inverter
Source title: ICECE 2018 - 10th International Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering

Authors with affiliations: Fatama-Tuz-Zahura, Department of Electrical Electronic Engineering, Bangladesh University of Engineering Technology, Dhaka, 1205, Bangladesh; Khan, M.Z.R., Department of Electrical Electronic Engineering, Bangladesh University of Engineering Technology, Dhaka, 1205, Bangladesh
Abstract: A design of voltage current control system for the grid-connected inverter is proposed here. The controller can also be used for energy storage systems (ESSs). The voltage control system represented in this paper is based on an adaptive PI controller which provides very low dc-link voltage fluctuations fast transient response. The current control strategy used here can optimize the transient error eliminate steady-state error. Simulations are performed on MATLAB Simulink. The effectiveness of the designed system is checked by comparing the simulation results with the results available in the literature. The proposed system can be used for improving the transient response of the grid-connected bidirectional inverters. © 2018 IEEE.

Authors: Abo-Al-Ez K.M.
Title: Optimum cluster of distributed generation systems for energy management within a virtual utility
Source title: Proceedings of the Conference on the Industrial and Commercial Use of Energy, ICUE
Affiliations: Centre for Distributed Power and Electronics Systems (CDPES), Cape Peninsula University of Technology (CPUT), PO Box 1906, Bellville, 7535, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Abo-Al-Ez, K.M., Centre for Distributed Power and Electronics Systems (CDPES), Cape Peninsula University of Technology (CPUT), PO Box 1906, Bellville, 7535, South Africa
Abstract: Many remote communities in developing countries suffer from lack or weak grid connection. A reliable electric energy system is essential for the residential and small industrial applications. In modern smart grids, the concept of virtual utility is used to describe a cluster of hybrid Distributed Generation (DG) and storage systems. The optimum cluster of DG and storage systems within a virtual utility is essential for a reliable energy management system, to effectively supply the load demands. This requires the minimization of the Net Present Cost (NPC) of the cluster's investment. Among various economic evaluation software tools, very effective software according to recent research and projects is the Hybrid Optimization Model for Electric Renewables (HOMER). In this paper, a remote load is used as a case study for economic evaluation of a cluster of DG resources. The available resources for the case study include PV arrays, small wind turbines, and a Hydrogen Fuel cell system along with storage battery banks. Optimization and sensitivity analysis results are thoroughly presented and discussed. © 2018 Cape Peninsula University of technology.
Author Keywords: Distributed Generation; HOMER; Optimization; Optimum cluster; Sensitivity analysis; Virtual utility

Authors: Lloyd P.J.
Title: The evolution of a major power grid
Source title: Proceedings of the Conference on the Industrial and Commercial Use of Energy, ICUE
Affiliations: Energy Institute, Cape Peninsula University of Technology, Bellville, 7535, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Lloyd, P.J., Energy Institute, Cape Peninsula University of Technology, Bellville, 7535, South Africa
Abstract: Seven years ago, the UK depended on coal-fired power to a large extent. Since then, the contribution of coal to the supply has been driven to a very low level. Some of the coal-fired stations have been converted to biomass, using imported wood pellets. Most have been replaced by combined-cycle gas turbine stations that are inherently more efficient and also, using natural gas as the fuel, less carbon intensive than coal. Nuclear makes a stable contribution, and hydropower and pumped storage make small contributions. Wind power has grown, and there were periods when it contributed over 8000MW to the grid - but also periods when it contributed less than 100MW. Latterly solar has entered the supply mix. These moves are tracked using the 5-minute data of Gridwatch, which also allows an assessment of the impact of non-dispatchable power on grid performance. Solar power appears to present particular challenges. The role of interconnections to Europe is also significant in the overall supply picture. These results are discussed in terms of plans to increase the nuclear contribution significantly in the near future, and the implications these findings might have for South Africa's desire to reduce its reliance on coal power for generation of electricity. © 2018 Cape Peninsula University of technology.
Author Keywords: Gridwatch; Power grid; UK electricity
Index Keywords: Coal; Combined cycle power plants; Combustion; Digital storage; Gas turbines; Solar energy; Wind power; Coal-fired power; Coal-fired stations; Combined cycle gas turbine; Grid performance; Gridwatch; Nuclear contribution; Power grids; Pumped Storage; Electric power transmission networks

Authors: Wang Z., Wang T., Zhao G., Li J.
Title: Coordinated optimization of the performance of processors and memory in a heterogeneous system under energy constraints
Source title: Proceedings - 2018 15th International Symposium on Pervasive Systems, Algorithms and Networks, I-SPAN 2018
Affiliations: School of Computers, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou, China; School of Automation, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Wang, Z., School of Computers, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou, China; Wang, T., School of Automation, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou, China; Zhao, G., School of Computers, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou, China; Li, J., School of Automation, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou, China
Abstract: As the power consumed by systems continues to increase, reducing their power consumption is one of the goals of system optimization. However, power consumption is also gradually becoming one of the important constraints that affects the design and implementation of the system. At present, research on optimization with energy constraints is mainly focused on optimizing the energy of the processors, but the energy consumed by off-chip memory accounts for a large proportion of the total consumed by the whole system. In this research, we investigate the coordinated optimization of the performance of the processors and memory for a heterogeneous system subject to energy constraints. A communication-computation pipeline for parallel programs is constructed to optimize program performance by simultaneously scaling the voltage and frequency of the processors and memory using a task partition strategy. Our experimental results indicate that our method of optimizing system performance by coordinating task partition and frequency scaling under energy constraints can result in a satisfying execution time and processor profit and meet the given energy constraints. © 2018 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Energy constraints; Heterogeneous system; Memory; Performance; Processors
Index Keywords: Data storage equipment; Dynamic frequency scaling; Electric power utilization; Program processors; Coordinated optimization; Design and implementations; Energy constraint; Frequency-scaling; Heterogeneous systems; Performance; Program performance; System optimizations; Pipeline processing systems

Authors: Zhang G., Zhu X., Bao W., Tan D., Yan H., Chen J.
Title: A novel server consolidation method based on local storage integrated with resource demand prediction
Source title: Proceedings - 2018 15th International Symposium on Pervasive Systems, Algorithms and Networks, I-SPAN 2018
Affiliations: College of Systems Engineering, National University of Defense Technology, Changsha, 410073, China; State Key Laboratory of High Performance Computing, National University of Defense Technology, Changsha, 410073, China; College of Computer Science, National University of Defense Technology, Changsha, 410073, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, G., College of Systems Engineering, National University of Defense Technology, Changsha, 410073, China; Zhu, X., College of Systems Engineering, National University of Defense Technology, Changsha, 410073, China, State Key Laboratory of High Performance Computing, National University of Defense Technology, Changsha, 410073, China; Bao, W., College of Systems Engineering, National University of Defense Technology, Changsha, 410073, China; Tan, D., College of Systems Engineering, National University of Defense Technology, Changsha, 410073, China; Yan, H., College of Computer Science, National University of Defense Technology, Changsha, 410073, China; Chen, J., College of Systems Engineering, National University of Defense Technology, Changsha, 410073, China
Abstract: Server consolidation plays a significant part in energy-saving technology in data centers. Traditionally, cloud service instances commonly use shared storage architecture. Nowadays, data and I/O intensive applications are preferred in this big data era and are used in the majority of Internet companies, much more attention has been paid to the local storage that offer perform better in I/O at a lower price compared with shared storage clouds. But these cloud instances usually contain much more data than shared storage cloud instances. Thus, in such local storage based clouds, the migration cost can be really high. Unfortunately, most existing work about did not consider integrating the demand prediction algorithm that plays a significant part in server consolidation, especially for local storage based cloud, where the migration cost is very high and is in badly need of an efficient resource pre-allocation mechanism. To address this issue, we proposes Aricon, a consolidation method based on local storage. Our approach uses a time series model to forecast the CPU or memory utilization of instances within servers. We investigate the effectiveness of instance and server resource utilization prediction in server consolidation performance in workload traces from real world. To validate the performance of the proposed Aricon, we test the prediction accuracy and compare it several existing consolidation method, and the results show that Aricon not only has low prediction error rate in 10.7% but also schedules computing resources efficiently. © 2018 IEEE.
Author Keywords: ARIMA; Cloud Computing; Consolidation; Local Storage; Resource Demand Estimation
Index Keywords: Cloud computing; Consolidation; Energy conservation; Forecasting; Memory architecture; Allocation mechanism; ARIMA; Consolidation methods; Energy-saving technologies; Prediction error rates; Resource demands; Server consolidation; Time series modeling; Digital storage

Authors: Zhang D., Bie Z.
Title: A high performance framework for large-scale 2D convolution operation on FPGA
Source title: Proceedings - 2018 15th International Symposium on Pervasive Systems, Algorithms and Networks, I-SPAN 2018
Affiliations: School of Information and Communication Engineering, Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, D., School of Information and Communication Engineering, Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications, Beijing, China; Bie, Z., School of Information and Communication Engineering, Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications, Beijing, China
Abstract: Convolutional neural network (CNN), as the focus in the artificial intelligence field, has attracted more and more attention resent years. Various accelerators based on FPGA platform have been proposed because of the high performance and high energy efficiency. However, limited to the on-chip memory resources, only small networks can be accelerated by these accelerators. Due to the fact that 2D convolution operation is the most computing-intensive part, accelerating large-scale 2D convolution operation has become the key to accelerating large-scale CNNs on FPGA platforms. This paper presents a method of rotary data-storage and a design of the new PE (processing unit). Compared to the traditional Z-type PE, it performs non-redundant calculations when the stride of convolution operation is greater than 1, which significantly reduces the calculating time. At the same time, in order to reduce the external memory bandwidth with limited on-chip resources, two optimization architectures and a block-calculation method have been proposed, which can reduce the usage of on-chip memory resources. As a case study, we select some convolution layers of ResNet-34 and compare it with a previous accelerator. Under the condition of same consumption of resources, the result shows that the proposed framework needs only 29.9% time and 51% external memory bandwidth of the previous accelerator. © 2018 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Acceleration; Convolution; FPGA; Memory bandwidth
Index Keywords: Acceleration; Bandwidth; Digital storage; Energy efficiency; Field programmable gate arrays (FPGA); Image coding; Neural networks; Calculating time; Convolutional neural network; External memory; High energy efficiency; Memory bandwidths; Optimization architecture; Performance frameworks; Processing units; Convolution

Authors: Wang S., Zhang S., Ding G., Li C., Cheng Y., Sun S.
Title: Adaptive Control of Power Electronics Load Considering User Intention in Islanded Microgrid
Source title: 2018 IEEE 4th Southern Power Electronics Conference, SPEC 2018
Affiliations: Power Grid Technology Center, State Grid Shandong Electric Power Research Institute, Jinan, China; Grid Maintenance Department, State Grid of China Technology College, Jinan, China; School of Electrical Engineering, University of Jinan, Jinan, China
Authors with affiliations: Wang, S., Power Grid Technology Center, State Grid Shandong Electric Power Research Institute, Jinan, China; Zhang, S., Grid Maintenance Department, State Grid of China Technology College, Jinan, China; Ding, G., School of Electrical Engineering, University of Jinan, Jinan, China; Li, C., School of Electrical Engineering, University of Jinan, Jinan, China; Cheng, Y., Power Grid Technology Center, State Grid Shandong Electric Power Research Institute, Jinan, China; Sun, S., Power Grid Technology Center, State Grid Shandong Electric Power Research Institute, Jinan, China
Abstract: Load control and management is a significant component for a microgrid with intermittent renewable power. In this paper, application of the flexible power electronics loads (FPELs) to balance the distributed power generations and loads demand in islanded microgrid is discussed. An adaptive control considering the user intention is proposed to make FPELs actively participate in the supply and demand balance of microgrid. In the proposed control, the frequency of microgrid is used as a control variable which indicates the balance between supply and demand. The multi-threshold frequency values are preset according the FPELs intention. The FPELs can regular their consumptions according to the microgrid operation and the user's intention. It can make the FPELs to automatically participate into the supply and demand balance and maintain the FPELs in proper operation. With the user intention, it can reduce the influence on load operation. In the control, the FPELs can automatically follow the microgrid operation without communication. Consequently, communication links and energy storage reservation can be reduced. Simulation studies are conducted via Matlab and the results show the effectiveness of the proposed control scheme. © 2018 IEEE.
Author Keywords: adaptive control; flexible power electronics loads; Microgrid; user intention

Authors: Mansuwan K., Jirapong P., Burana S., Thararak P.
Title: Optimal Planning and Operation of Battery Energy Storage Systems in Smart Grids Using Improved Genetic Algorithm Based Intelligent Optimization Tool
Source title: Proceedings of the Conference on the Industrial and Commercial Use of Energy, ICUE
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Chiang Mai University, Chiang Mai, Thailand; Graduate School, Chiang Mai University, Chiang Mai, Thailand; Provincial Electricity Authority, Bangkok, Thailand
Authors with affiliations: Mansuwan, K., Department of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Chiang Mai University, Chiang Mai, Thailand, Graduate School, Chiang Mai University, Chiang Mai, Thailand, Provincial Electricity Authority, Bangkok, Thailand; Jirapong, P., Department of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Chiang Mai University, Chiang Mai, Thailand; Burana, S., Department of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Chiang Mai University, Chiang Mai, Thailand, Graduate School, Chiang Mai University, Chiang Mai, Thailand; Thararak, P., Department of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Chiang Mai University, Chiang Mai, Thailand, Graduate School, Chiang Mai University, Chiang Mai, Thailand
Abstract: In this paper, an improved genetic algorithm (IGA) implemented with reliable power system analysis tool is developed to determine the optimal planning and operation of battery energy storage system (BESS) in smart grid with photovoltaic (PV) generation. The main objectives are maximizing benefit from energy losses reduction and energy shaving enhancement, while minimizing the investment cost. Double layers optimization technique is implemented for determining the BESS siting and sizing in the first layer, while the maximum energy shaving is calculated in the second layer. The IGA implemented in MATLAB and DIgSILENT programs utilizing an automatic data exchange process is utilized for solving the optimal solution. This approach is tested on a practical 22 kV distribution network of Thailand to present the effectiveness of decision-making support tool. The simulation results show that the optimal BESS planning results in mitigating PV intermittency and improvement in smart grid efficiency. © 2018 Asian Institute of Technology.

Authors: Feng P., Yang P., Shang Z., Zhu Z.
Title: Topology Derivation of Non-isolated Multi-Port DC-DC Converters Based on H-Bridge
Source title: 2018 IEEE 4th Southern Power Electronics Conference, SPEC 2018

Abstract: From the point of building bidirectional power flow path for the energy storage element (ESE), this paper proposes a general approach to develop multi-port converters (MPCs) by connecting the ESE-centric H-bridge cell with source or load of the classic converter. Six configurations are presented by investigating the connecting principles between H-bridge and the source or load of the classic converter. Derived by combining the six configurations with the classic converter, the obtained MPCs feature single-inductor and single-stage power conversion among the ports. The operating characteristics and port voltage restriction of MPCs are analyzed and compared. Experimental results of the proposed MPCs, named L-3-buck/boost, are presented to verify the analysis results. © 2018 IEEE.

Title: A Review on Re-Utilization of Electric Vehicle's Retired Batteries
Source title: Proceedings of the Conference on the Industrial and Commercial Use of Energy, ICUE

Abstract: The utilization of batteries as a primary source for energy recovery and energy storage applications such as solar energy, wind energy, hybrid system and electric vehicles has been increasing rapidly now days. This paper reviews about the utilization methods of retired batteries from transportation sectors. It also describes the classification of chemical storage batteries, their characteristics, benefits and challenges while utilizing retired batteries, and some of the application aspects. The importance of retired batteries along with an integration of building block system is presented in this paper. © 2018 Asian Institute of Technology.

Authors: Nahas E.W., Mansour D.-E.A., Abd El-Ghany H.A., Eissa M.M.
Title: Accurate Fault Analysis and Proposed Protection Scheme for Battery Energy Storage System Integrated with DC Microgrids
Source title: 2018 20th International Middle East Power Systems Conference, MEPCON 2018 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Faculty of Engineering, Tanta University, Department of Electrical Power and Machines Engineering, Tanta, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Nahas, E.W., Faculty of Engineering, Tanta University, Department of Electrical Power and Machines Engineering, Tanta, Egypt; Mansour, D.-E.A., Faculty of Engineering, Tanta University, Department of Electrical Power and Machines Engineering, Tanta, Egypt; Abd El-Ghany, H.A., Faculty of Engineering, Tanta University, Department of Electrical Power and Machines Engineering, Tanta, Egypt; Eissa, M.M., Faculty of Engineering, Tanta University, Department of Electrical Power and Machines Engineering, Tanta, Egypt
Abstract: The paper introduces non-unit protection scheme for the battery energy storage system (BESS). BESS is considered a vital source for microgrid operation. The most important challenge faced by the DC microgrid is the growth of fault current and consequently the rising rate. Because of the BESS has larger fault current contribution, fast detecting and isolating for the faults at BESS are required. The developed protection scheme is based on local measurements without the need for communication channel. Consequently, the relay operation is enhanced from avoiding the delay and any failure can be occurred in the communication media. For an accurate and fast protection scheme, the current derivative at BESS is analytically derived. During high impedance faults, the current derivative can fail in fault detection. So, the relay sensitivity is improved by taking the voltage derivative as a complementary feature for fault detection and discrimination in such critical cases. The fault analysis was carried out by selecting proper threshold values for the voltage and current derivative. Validation of the protection scheme is presented for several cases including internal and external faults and the relay operation showed satisfied results in DC microgrid protection. © 2018 IEEE.
Author Keywords: BESS; DC microgrid; Fault analysis; protection scheme
Index Keywords: Electric batteries; Electric fault currents; Fault detection; Battery energy storage systems; BESS; Complementary features; Dc micro-grid; Detection and discriminations; Fast protection schemes; Fault analysis; Protection schemes; Battery storage

Authors: Eid M.A.E., Abdelwahab S.A.M., Ibrahim H.A., Alaboudy A.H.K.
Title: Improving the Resiliency of a PV Standalone System under Variable Solar Radiation and Load Profile
Source title: 2018 20th International Middle East Power Systems Conference, MEPCON 2018 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Electrical Department, Faculty of Industrial Education, Suez University, Suez, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Eid, M.A.E., Electrical Department, Faculty of Industrial Education, Suez University, Suez, Egypt; Abdelwahab, S.A.M., Electrical Department, Faculty of Industrial Education, Suez University, Suez, Egypt; Ibrahim, H.A., Electrical Department, Faculty of Industrial Education, Suez University, Suez, Egypt; Alaboudy, A.H.K., Electrical Department, Faculty of Industrial Education, Suez University, Suez, Egypt
Abstract: The standalone PV system is controlled using the maximum power point tracking (MPPT) algorithm under the impact of the fixed or changing solar irradiation, and the system is interconnected to battery energy storage (BES) to produce power for variable AC loads. The system comprises of PV array, a battery, (DC/DC) boost converter circuit, single phase inverter with LCL filter, and bidirectional (DC/DC) buck-boost converter perform as charging circuit. The maximum power point (MPP) be able to obtained by controlling the duty cycle fed to the gate of the IGBT transistor located within the boost circuit. Moreover, the control method used with both the single-phase inverter and the buck-boost converter circuit is a dynamic error driven PI controller. This paper studies the performance comparison of PV standalone system in two cases of operation. In the first case, the system operates without and with battery under constant solar irradiation. In the second case, the PV system is interconnect to a battery and operates under a variable in solar radiation. In addition to presenting the operating results of the system for the two cases mentioned previously, harmonic analysis is performed on these results using FFT tools. The research paper works on presenting the operating results of the system in the above-mentioned cases and clarifies the following points: loads management, stable load voltage level, harmonic analysis through FFT tools, charging and discharging the BES and transient overshoot. © 2018 IEEE.
Author Keywords: and bidirectional buck-boost converter; battery energy storage; loads management; MPPT; PV array

Authors: Betti A.M., Ebrahim M.A., Mustafa Hassan M.A.
Title: Modeling and Control of Stand-alone PV System Based on Fractional-Order PID Controller
Source title: 2018 20th International Middle East Power Systems Conference, MEPCON 2018 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Electrical Power Dept, Faculty of Engineering, Cairo University, Giza, Egypt; Electrical Engineering Dept., Faculty of Engineering at Shoubra, Benha University, Cairo, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Betti, A.M., Electrical Power Dept, Faculty of Engineering, Cairo University, Giza, Egypt; Ebrahim, M.A., Electrical Engineering Dept., Faculty of Engineering at Shoubra, Benha University, Cairo, Egypt; Mustafa Hassan, M.A., Electrical Power Dept, Faculty of Engineering, Cairo University, Giza, Egypt
Abstract: In this paper, an efficient energy management scheme for stand-alone photovoltaic microgrid system (SAPVMS) is elaborated. The proposed fractional order (FO) PID and PI based energy management scheme comprises of two control loops namely inner and outer loops to outperform a standalone PV system with satisfactory response. The main task of the inner control loop is to extract and track maximum power from SAPVMS with sufficient tracking behavior. Moreover, the outer control loop is equipped with the battery for controlling the power between the source and the load smoothly. Particle swarm optimization (PSO) is working to fine tune the proposed control loops by generating their optimal settings. The integral of the absolute error multiplied by time is utilized to define the proposed system objective function. Various scenarios include sun irradiance variations and load fluctuations are presented to demonstrate the theoretical analysis, effectiveness of the offered energy management strategy. Further validations for numerical results attained by PSO are made compared with classical controllers such as PI and PID which signify the tuned FOPID and FOPI gains. The model results of the entire SAPVMS are described given along with comprehensive simulation results that discover the feasibility of the system. © 2018 IEEE.

Authors: Pournoori N., Ukkonen L., Bjorninen T.
Title: Charge Storage Level Indicator for RF Energy Harvester based on Dual-ID Passive UHF RFID Tag
Source title: 2018 12th International Symposium on Antennas, Propagation and EM Theory, ISAPE 2018 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Faculty of Biomedical Sciences and Engineering, BioMediTech Institute, Tampere University of Technology, Tampere, Finland

Abstract: Far-field RF energy harvesting is a convincing approach for energizing low-power wireless devices. In this work, we present a passive UHF RFID tag combined with an RF-energy harvester where a low-power switch circuitry changes the tag's ID as the voltage at the harvester's storage capacitor exceeds a certain threshold. This way, an RFID reader can receive the information on when the system is ready for running more advanced and energy-consuming functionalities. As a summary, our system switches the tag's ID as the voltage at the storage capacitor exceeds 0.7 V and our simulations predict that both tag IDs can be detected at the distance of more than 4.8 m while conforming to European UHF RFID emission regulations. © 2018 IEEE.

Authors: Ali Z.M., Abusief F., Kamel S.
Title: Voltage Profile Enhancement for Remote Areas Through Renewable Energy Resources Integration
Source title: 2018 20th International Middle East Power Systems Conference, MEPCON 2018 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Aswan University, Aswan, 81542, Egypt; Department of Electrical Engineering, Tobruk University, Libya, Libyan Arab Jamahiriya

Abstract: Power quality determines the fitness of electric power to consumer. Hence, it's considered very important issue in the operation of electrical systems, relates to the resolution of the problems of continuity of service or the malfunction of the end-user equipment. Remote and isolated communities such as villages and islands are often subject to substantial and repeated power outages due to the weakness of the power lines connecting to the main network. This paper investigates the possibility of improving the quality of supply in remote areas using distributed energy resources (DERs) such as; PV, wind, solar or hybrid sources depending on the environmental conditions of these areas. A comprehensive study related to power quality improvement for a realistic model for Aswan Island network that located in Southern Egypt is presented. PV with storage battery and diesel power generation units are connected at the weakest voltage point in the system. DigSelient commercial software is used to simulate the case understudy. Different simulation scenarios are performed to compare and evaluate the overall power quality for the system with DERs. © 2018 IEEE.
Author Keywords: DERs; Micro grid; Power quality; PV; Voltage profile

Title: Short-Term Frequency Stability Regulation for Power System with Large-Scale Wind Energy Penetration Using PID Controller
Source title: 2018 20th International Middle East Power Systems Conference, MEPCON 2018 - Proceedings

Abstract: Energy storage schemes play important role in stabilizing grid frequency, specifically, with high wind power penetration. In this paper, different controller types have been used to adjust the flow of storage power through an appropriate power converter. Step response is studied for PI, PID, and non-linear PID controllers to define proper controller for short-term frequency stability support. A conventional generator emulator is proposed. PID controller shows significant improvement in frequency behavior of studied cases. © 2018 IEEE.

Authors: Ghimire S., Marasini J., Adhikari R.
Title: Technical and Engineering Reforms of Integrated Nepal Power System for Security Enhancement
Source title: Proceedings of 2019 3rd IEEE International Conference on Electrical, Computer and Communication Technologies, ICECCT 2019
Affiliations: Institute of Engineering, Tribhuvan University, Nepal
Authors with affiliations: Ghimire, S., Institute of Engineering, Tribhuvan University, Nepal; Marasini, J., Institute of Engineering, Tribhuvan University, Nepal; Adhikari, R., Institute of Engineering, Tribhuvan University, Nepal
Abstract: Power system security and reliability are the most essential aspects of today's power market. Ensuring continuous supply of power meeting the desired quality standards are crucial. If any power system exhibit inability to do so then it needs to be reformed and updated in all required aspects. This paper deals with technical/engineering reforms of INPS for security enhancement, beginning with reviews of the existing power trade conditions of INPS with India while also identifying power trade relation opportunities with China, Bangladesh and Bhutan, followed by consumer level reforms needed for power quality improvement and concluded with addressing the need of generation planning and introducing new technology to fulfill the paper's objective. Hence, issues and solutions related to all the three aspects, generation, transmission and distribution are addressed here. This paper mentions the efficacy of prioritizing loads differently to different sectors as well as scheduling of industrial loads so as not to interrupt power supplies to higher priority loads. The technical issues, negative and positive, of ROR, PROR and storage type hydropower has been discussed briefly and the need of a country to build large scale hydropower plants rather than several small hydropower plants has been clarified with associated technical difficulties. Necessary technical changes in generation and distribution side has been suggested based on security and reliability viewpoint. Also, the necessary adaptations in the transmission network as per the changes suggested in generation side are forwarded. Hence, this paper provides a track for technical improvement of INPS taking into consideration the hand-in-hand growth of all three parts with simultaneous involvement of related authorities. © 2019 IEEE.

Authors: Miyake S., Kudtongngam J., Iwamura K., Nakanishi Y.
Title: Optimizing the Facility Planning in BEMS Using HOMER for Expandable Micro-Grids Clusters
Source title: 2019 IEEE Power and Energy Society Innovative Smart Grid Technologies Conference, ISGT 2019
Authors with affiliations: Miyake, S.; Kudtongngam, J.; Iwamura, K.; Nakanishi, Y.
Abstract: In recent years, the popularity of micro-grids has been growing with the rapid growth of renewable resources. In addition, a significant part of the energy globally consumed could be attributed to the building sector. Thus, to develop the expandable micro-grid clusters (EMGCs), the authors investigate optimal facility planning in the building energy management system (BEMS), which is one of the important component of EMGCs. To optimize the total facility cost of BEMS, the hybrid optimization of multiple energy resources, i.e., HOMER, a simulation tool developed by the U.S. Department of Energy's National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL), is applied. A BEMS is simulated using photovoltaic generation, battery storage, a converter, and a load. The authors vary the eight types of battery capacity and investigate the correlation among the whole system for optimizing the facility configuration by minimizing the facility's lifecycle cost. The simulations reveal the optimal facility configuration that minimizes long-term costs. © 2019 IEEE.

Authors: Rokocakau S., Mudaliar H., Kumar D., Aitchison D., Cirrincione M., Mohammadi A.
Title: A flywheel energy storage system in a microgrid for powering small villages in remote islands in the south pacific
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE International Conference on Industrial Technology
Affiliations: School of Engineering and Physics, University of the South Pacific, Laucala Campus, Suva, Fiji
Authors with affiliations: Rokocakau, S., School of Engineering and Physics, University of the South Pacific, Laucala Campus, Suva, Fiji; Mudaliar, H., School of Engineering and Physics, University of the South Pacific, Laucala Campus, Suva, Fiji; Kumar, D., School of Engineering and Physics, University of the South Pacific, Laucala Campus, Suva, Fiji; Aitchison, D., School of Engineering and Physics, University of the South Pacific, Laucala Campus, Suva, Fiji; Cirrincione, M., School of Engineering and Physics, University of the South Pacific, Laucala Campus, Suva, Fiji; Mohammadi, A., School of Engineering and Physics, University of the South Pacific, Laucala Campus, Suva, Fiji
Abstract: In most Pacific Island Countries (PICs), the populations reside in isolated communities where electricity generation is hard to access and therefore these communities are heavily dependent on fossil fuel based generation plants. One way to reduce the dependence on these fuels is to use the abundant, albeit intermittent, Renewable Energy Sources (RES). At present most RES based microgrids (MGs) use lead acid battery batteries as the only way to store energy, which can be detrimental for the environment. This paper proposes to minimize the ecological impact support them by using Flywheel Energy Storage Systems (FESS) so as to reduce the size of battery strings required or increase the storage performance of the MG. A case study on data for a small village in Taveuni (Fiji) is presented and the advantages of using a FESS as a back-up storage system are highlighted and discussed. © 2019 IEEE.
