Authors: Jiang T.
Title: Multi-objective optimal scheduling method for regional photovoltaic-storage-charging integrated system participating in demand response
Source title: IET Conference Publications
Affiliations: Institute of Electrical Engineering, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Jiang, T., Institute of Electrical Engineering, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou, China
Abstract: With the development of photovoltaic power generation and the popularity of electric vehicles, the integrated system of regional photovoltaic-storage-charging emerges as the times require. In this paper, the optimal scheduling problem in the operation of photovoltaic-storage-charging integrated system under the condition of grid connection is studied. This paper introduces the structure, basic composition unit and operation strategy of optical storage and charge integrated system under time-sharing electricity price. Considering the demand response of the charging load of the electric vehicle and the basic electric load of the village area, the transferable load of the peak and trough of the electricity price is determined. A two-objective optimization model is established to reduce the load peak and valley difference and improve the economy of the integrated optical storage and charging system, and the NSGA-II algorithm is used to solve it. Finally, an example is given to prove the effectiveness and feasibility of the proposed model and algorithm. © 2019 Institution of Engineering and Technology. All rights reserved.

Authors: Pan P., Chen W., Mu H.
Title: Decentralized unified control strategy for medium and low voltage DC distribution power system
Source title: IET Conference Publications
Affiliations: School of Electrical Engineering, Southeast University, Nanjing, China
Authors with affiliations: Pan, P., School of Electrical Engineering, Southeast University, Nanjing, China; Chen, W., School of Electrical Engineering, Southeast University, Nanjing, China; Mu, H., School of Electrical Engineering, Southeast University, Nanjing, China
Abstract: Distributed photovoltaic (PV) accessed to DC distribution power system (DPS) from multi-port is a major form to promote the consumption of renewable energy, but the increase of PV permeability will lead to the deterioration of the system stability. Traditional analysis usually concentrates on the DC micro-grid and the analysis of DC DPS with multi-voltage levels, such as medium and low voltage DC DPS, is rarely involved. This paper proposes a decentralized unified control strategy for the medium and low voltage DC DPS. It is composed of two parts, one is the decentralized control strategy based on the DC bus voltage signal (DBS) for the PV, storage and fuel cell units on the DC bus; one is the unified control strategy for the DC transformer integrating the power control, medium voltage and low voltage DC bus voltage regulation functions. Consequently, it avoids the control mode switching of DC transformer and can achieve the global power sharing of the system. Finally, the equivalent simulation model of medium and low voltage DC DPS is built in Matlab/Simulink and simulation analysis of multiple operating states and scenarios is carried out to validate the effectiveness of the proposed control strategy. © 2019 Institution of Engineering and Technology. All rights reserved.

Authors: Tian K., Sun W., Yang C., Han D., Zhang W., Xi P.
Title: Generation-grid-storage coordinated planning method with renewable portfolio standard
Source title: IET Conference Publications
Affiliations: Department of Control Science and Engineering, University of Shanghai for Science and Technology, Shanghai, 200093, China; Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Shanghai for Science and Technology, Shanghai, 200093, China; Shanghai Key Laboratory of Smart Grid Demand Response, Shanghai, 200063, China

Abstract: The key to fulfill the quota is to consider the renewable energy accommodation in the planning stage of power system with renewables portfolio standards. Based on the renewable energy quota index, this paper proposes a coordinated planning method to improve the accommodation capacity of power system from three aspects: generation, grid and energy storage to complete the renewable energy quota index. In this method, using time series production simulation to characterize the time varying characteristics of renewable energy and load. Considering the uncertainty of renewable energy and dynamic operation constraints of power system, a two-stage robust optimization model satisfying the quota index of renewable energy is established. This model has a min-max-min structure and nonlinear constraints, which is reformulated into mixed integer linear programming (MILP) that can be solved by commercial software by using duality theory and Big-M method, and the uncertainty budget parameter are introduced to reduce the conservatism of the scheme. Finally, based on the example of IEEE RTS-24 node system, the influence of renewable energy quota index on the planning results is analyzed, and the effectiveness of the coordinated planning model is verified. © 2019 Institution of Engineering and Technology. All rights reserved.

Authors: Wang M., Chen L., He P., Tao W.
Title: Numerical study of CaO/Ca(OH)2 dehydration process with a porous channel
Source title: Proceedings of the Thermal and Fluids Engineering Summer Conference
Affiliations: Key Laboratory of Thermo-Fluid Science and Engineering of MOE, School of Energy and Power Engineering, Xi’an Jiaotong University, Xi’an, Shaanxi, 710049, China

Abstract: Thermochemical energy storage is an effective method of energy storage with high energy density and little heat loss. The physicochemical model of dehydration process is established based on the chemical kinetic regulation of dehydration process, coupling with fluid flow and heat transfer. The dehydration process of CaO/Ca(OH)2 in an undirected cylindrical reaction unit with constant wall temperature is studied. Mechanism of chemical reaction combined with heat transfer and fluid flow is analyzed first. Then, dehydration processes at different wall temperature and outlet pressure conditions are studied. Results indicate that higher wall temperature can significantly shorten reaction time while change of outlet pressure here has little impact on reaction time. To enhance the equilibrium of dehydration process, porous channels, of different permeability and solid frame thermal conductivity, are inserted into the reaction unit. Porous channel not only promotes the flow of vapour but also improves heat transfer and the corresponding reaction time is significantly reduced. © 2019 Begell House Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Dehydration; Numerical simulation; Porosity; Porous channel; Thermochemical energy storage

Authors: Hu Y., Zhou C., Yan Z., Li P., Ma X., Lei J., Yuan Z.
Title: Economic feasibility analysis of using battery energy storage to reduce renewable generation curtailment in CSG
Source title: IET Conference Publications
Affiliations: Electric Power Research Institute, CSG, No. 11, Kexiang Road, Science City, Huangpu District, Guangzhou, China
Authors with affiliations: Hu, Y., Electric Power Research Institute, CSG, No. 11, Kexiang Road, Science City, Huangpu District, Guangzhou, China; Zhou, C., Electric Power Research Institute, CSG, No. 11, Kexiang Road, Science City, Huangpu District, Guangzhou, China; Yan, Z., Electric Power Research Institute, CSG, No. 11, Kexiang Road, Science City, Huangpu District, Guangzhou, China; Li, P., Electric Power Research Institute, CSG, No. 11, Kexiang Road, Science City, Huangpu District, Guangzhou, China; Ma, X., Electric Power Research Institute, CSG, No. 11, Kexiang Road, Science City, Huangpu District, Guangzhou, China; Lei, J., Electric Power Research Institute, CSG, No. 11, Kexiang Road, Science City, Huangpu District, Guangzhou, China; Yuan, Z., Electric Power Research Institute, CSG, No. 11, Kexiang Road, Science City, Huangpu District, Guangzhou, China
Abstract: Based on real data, this paper studies the economic feasibility of using battery energy storage (BES) to reduce curtailment of renewable energy generation in China Southern Power Grid (CSG). Firstly, areas in CSG with most renewable generation curtailment are identified, and new methods to estimate and correct the abandoned renewable power are proposed in this paper, since the conventional model machine method is no longer applicable in highland mountains. Secondly, the necessary installed capacities of BES and power conversion system (PCS) are dimensioned based on emulated operations of BES. Finally, the investments of necessary BES capacity to accommodate abandoned renewable power and its payback periods are calculated. It is found that, in CSG, there is no scenario where BES is competitive to facilitate renewable energy accommodation due to low utilization. The initial investment of BES is huge and the payback period is very long. In comparison, most of abandoned wind and solar power could have been accommodated by building additional substations or altering operation mode of existing substations with much lower cost. In the future, BES could become competitive when curtailment of renewable generation is more evenly distributed through a year and the cost of batteries declines. © 2019 Institution of Engineering and Technology. All rights reserved.

Authors: Zhang L., Xiao Y., Zhu Y.
Title: Voltage segment control of wind/PV hybrid islanded DC microgrid with multiple energy storages
Source title: IET Conference Publications
Affiliations: Beijing Polytechnic, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, L., Beijing Polytechnic, Beijing, China; Xiao, Y., Beijing Polytechnic, Beijing, China; Zhu, Y., Beijing Polytechnic, Beijing, China
Abstract: For power shortage and no electricity areas, building wind/pv hybrid islanded DC microgrid with multiple energy storages can reduce the power supply insufficient or imbalance caused by single energy. It can improve system performance and power supply reliability, and is advantageous to the complementary advantages and coordination control between various micro-sources. Ring topology is adopted with more flexibility and higher reliability. Then three different operation modes are proposed, that is energy storage voltage regulation mode, wind/pv power reduction mode, and load shedding mode. According to the regulation of DC voltage operating range, the voltage segment control strategy is proposed, to ensure energy storage units, power generation unit and loads are all involved in the coordinated control. They can adjust the DC voltage automatically according to their priorities. For multiple energy storage units, droop coefficient of droop control is adjusted dynamically based on load power share. In addition, control methods of converters in each voltage segment are analyzed to meet different operation requirements, such as changes of wind speed, intensity of light and loads, or energy storage reaching limit value. The control strategy can be extended to other distributed power-based DC microgrids. Finally, the proposed control is validated by simulations using MATLAB/Simulink. © 2019 Institution of Engineering and Technology. All rights reserved.

Authors: Wang J., Wu K., Zhu W., Feng L., Zhang X., Qi L., Gu C., Wang X.
Title: The restricted operation scenario screening strategy of distributed power based on shadow price
Source title: IET Conference Publications
Affiliations: State Grid Shandong Electric Power Research Institute, Jinan, Shandong, 250002, China; Economic and Technology Research Institute State Grid Shandong Electric Power Company, Jinan, Shandong, 250021, China; Shandong Electric Power Company, Jinan, Shandong, 250001, China

Abstract: In recent years, a large number of new elements such as distributed power, energy storage, and electric vehicles have been added to the distribution network, which enrich the operation scenario of the distribution network and result in more uncertain of the distribution network operation. In order to adapt to various distribution network operation scenarios and improve the ability of renewable energy consumption, this paper fully considers the various uncertainties of active distribution network, and establishes a quantitative analysis model of distributed power restriction. This paper proposes a restricted operation scenario screening strategy of distributed power based on shadow price by correcting the shadow price of network resources of the scheduling operation optimization model. Through this strategy, a set of restricted operation scenarios is obtained, and the screening results are incorporated into distributed power planning. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed strategy and model is verified by an extended IEEE33 node example. © 2019 Institution of Engineering and Technology. All rights reserved.

Authors: Cai Z., Ge Y., Huang J., Shi S., Xu D., Yan C.
Title: A multi-pattern coordinative scheduling for large capacity energy storage system
Source title: IET Conference Publications
Affiliations: China Electric Power Research Institute, Beijing, China; State Grid Liaoning Electric Power Supply Company, Shenyang, China; State Grid Dalian Electric Power Supply Company, Dalian, China
Authors with affiliations: Cai, Z., China Electric Power Research Institute, Beijing, China; Ge, Y., State Grid Liaoning Electric Power Supply Company, Shenyang, China; Huang, J., State Grid Dalian Electric Power Supply Company, Dalian, China; Shi, S., State Grid Liaoning Electric Power Supply Company, Shenyang, China; Xu, D., China Electric Power Research Institute, Beijing, China; Yan, C., China Electric Power Research Institute, Beijing, China
Abstract: With the development of energy storage technology and the reduction of construction costs, the battery energy storage power stations are changing from small capacity and joint scheduling of wind and light storage to large capacity and independent scheduling and operation. To this end, a multi-pattern coordinated scheduling method for the large-capacity vanadium redox energy storage power station is proposed; the operational characteristics of battery energy storage are analyzed. On this basis, the scheduling strategy of battery energy storage participating in power grid peak regulation, frequency modulation and the provision of standby is proposed; the wind power prediction error is fuzzified. Based on the credibility theory, a multi-pattern optimized scheduling model for vanadium redox battery energy storage based on fuzzy chance constraints is established. The model is solved through the mixed integer programming method. The model mentioned above is applied to practical examples. The simulation results show that the energy storage power station participating in multi-pattern applications can further improve the economy and safety of the power grid. © 2019 Institution of Engineering and Technology. All rights reserved.

Authors: Sun W., Qu C., Sun Y., Li J., Song R.
Title: Study on primary frequency regulation strategy of energy storage in photovoltaic power station
Source title: IET Conference Publications

Abstract: Large-scale integration of photovoltaic power generation will put a great deal of pressure on frequency regulation since PV do not have such inertia response features as synchronous generators do and their outputs are volatile and randomness. In order to improve photovoltaic power generation to participate in power grid frequency regulation capacity, it is necessary to introduce new supplementary means of frequency regulation and battery energy storage system (BESS) has an advantage here because of its rapid response feature. This paper firstly presents the technical requirements of energy storage participating in primary frequency regulation in China, and then puts forwards a frequency regulation technology scheme considering the state of charge of energy storage. Finally, two parallel operation models of energy storage converters are built in RTLAB real-time simulation platform to verify the effectiveness of the control strategy. © 2019 Institution of Engineering and Technology. Authors: Wei H., Yu S., Xiaoping L., Fang Y., Yang L.
Title: Topology and parameter design of power quality control device for medium voltage distribution network
Source title: IET Conference Publications
Affiliations: Electric Power Research Institute, State Grid Hubei Electric Power Co., Ltd, Wuhan, China
Authors with affiliations: Wei, H., Electric Power Research Institute, State Grid Hubei Electric Power Co., Ltd, Wuhan, China; Yu, S., Electric Power Research Institute, State Grid Hubei Electric Power Co., Ltd, Wuhan, China; Xiaoping, L., Electric Power Research Institute, State Grid Hubei Electric Power Co., Ltd, Wuhan, China; Fang, Y., Electric Power Research Institute, State Grid Hubei Electric Power Co., Ltd, Wuhan, China; Yang, L., Electric Power Research Institute, State Grid Hubei Electric Power Co., Ltd, Wuhan, China
Abstract: Power quality control device for medium voltage distribution network with source-load isolation is presented in this paper. It can solve many power quality problems, such as frequency fluctuation, voltage fluctuation, voltage flicker, voltage sag, short-term voltage, three-phase unbalance, harmonics, intermittent wave, temporary overvoltage and so on. It does not need to detect power quality events, and can realize seamless switching between grid side power supply and energy storage power supply when voltage sag and voltage short interruption, ensuring uninterrupted high quality power supply on the load side. A parameter design method considering redundancy of cascaded H-bridge is proposed, and a set of 1MVA power quality control device for medium voltage distribution network is developed. Experiments verify the effectiveness of the device parameter design method and the power quality management performance. An effective method for comprehensive improvement of power quality in distribution network is proposed. © 2019 Institution of Engineering and Technology. All rights reserved.

Abstract: China is performing the electricity market reform. With the increasing penetration of renewable energy, it is important to understand how the renewables influence the market performance. Renewables are different from the traditional generators in two aspects: 1) the marginal costs of renewable are small; 2) renewables cause fluctuations and increase the requirement of auxiliary service. In this paper, we analyse the influence of renewables on the market equilibrium. A multi-period Supply Function Equilibrium (SFE) model is formulated, where the upper level model maximizes individual profits of market participants, and the lower level model minimizes the market operational costs. To avoid the infeasibility of the equilibrium model, the relaxation of the complementary slackness condition is utilized. This paper exhibits how the increase of renewable penetrations affects the optimal bidding and profits of other market participants, including the traditional generators, hydro generator, and storage. The influence of renewables on the market equilibrium is exhibited as well. © 2019 Institution of Engineering and Technology. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Electricity Market; EPEC; Equilibrium Analysis; Renewable Energy
Index Keywords: Electric generators; Electric industry; Profitability; Electricity market equilibrium; Electricity market reforms; EPEC; Equilibrium analysis; Equilibrium modeling; Renewable energies; Renewable energy penetrations; Supply function equilibrium models; Power markets

Authors: Ge W., Wang T., Gao J., Wang Y., Wang S., Liang Y., Zhao D., Wang J., Huang B.
Title: Energy internet optimization scheduling for wind energy consumption considering high-energy load and electricity-to-gas
Source title: IET Conference Publications
Affiliations: State Grid Liaoning Electric Power Company Limited, Shenyang, China; State Grid Liaoning Economic Research Institute, Shenyang, China; School of Information Science and Technology, Northeastern University, Shenyang, China
Authors with affiliations: Ge, W., State Grid Liaoning Electric Power Company Limited, Shenyang, China; Wang, T., State Grid Liaoning Economic Research Institute, Shenyang, China; Gao, J., State Grid Liaoning Economic Research Institute, Shenyang, China; Wang, Y., State Grid Liaoning Economic Research Institute, Shenyang, China; Wang, S., State Grid Liaoning Electric Power Company Limited, Shenyang, China; Liang, Y., State Grid Liaoning Economic Research Institute, Shenyang, China; Zhao, D., State Grid Liaoning Economic Research Institute, Shenyang, China; Wang, J., School of Information Science and Technology, Northeastern University, Shenyang, China; Huang, B., School of Information Science and Technology, Northeastern University, Shenyang, China
Abstract: Energy Internet has deepened the connection between power grid, natural gas network and heat network, improving the flexibility of system operation. P2G deepens the coupling between the grid and natural gas network. The cooperation of P2G and energy storage device realizes the space-time translation of energy, which provides an effective way for new energy consumption and peak shaving and valley filling. High-energy load as a demand response with high energy efficiency is an effective form to promote wind power consumption. Considering the economics of system operation and the goal of maximizing the consumption of wind power, this paper proposes an energy Internet optimization scheduling strategy that comprehensively utilizes P2G equipment and high energy load. The load agent coordination layer collects schedulable information of high-energy enterprises and reports them to the dispatching center. The dispatching center issues a dispatching plan according to the objective function and the constraint conditions. In the objective function, in order to reflect the ability of the strategy to absorb wind power, a discarding penalty item is added. The effectiveness of the scheduling strategy is verified by an example to improve the economics of the system while maximizing the consumption of wind power. © 2019 Institution of Engineering and Technology. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Energy internet; High energy load; P2G; Wind power consumption
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electric power utilization; Energy efficiency; Energy utilization; Natural gas; Scheduling; Wind power; Agent coordination; Constraint conditions; Energy internet; High energy efficiency; Natural gas networks; Objective functions; Optimization scheduling; Scheduling strategies; Electric power transmission networks

Authors: Hueng X., Hong Y., Liu J., Jia P.
Title: Virtual inertia online control strategy for DC grid based on variable droop coefficient
Source title: IET Conference Publications
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Beijing Jiaotong University, Beijing, China; Department of Electrical Engineering, North China University of Technology, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Hueng, X., Department of Electrical Engineering, Beijing Jiaotong University, Beijing, China; Hong, Y., Department of Electrical Engineering, Beijing Jiaotong University, Beijing, China; Liu, J., Department of Electrical Engineering, Beijing Jiaotong University, Beijing, China; Jia, P., Department of Electrical Engineering, North China University of Technology, Beijing, China
Abstract: The access of renewable energy leads to greater randomness of DC power flow. Unified droop control strategy can ensure better stability of the system, but it has poor dynamic regulation ability for stochastic fluctuating power and has steady-state error. Based on the analysis of the relationship between the output impedance of the converter and the system inertia of the DC grid and the influence of the system inertia on the control characteristics of the DC grid, this paper proposes a control strategy to change the virtual system inertia by changing droop coefficient. Changing the virtual inertia of the system by adjusting the output impedance of the converter through exchanging the state information of online converters by low-speed communication, improves the dynamic and steady-state control characteristics of the system. Finally, a four-terminal MVDC power grid simulation system with PV and storage devices is established in MATLAB. The simulation results show that the proposed control strategy has better dynamic performance and improves the quality of MVDC voltage. © 2019 Institution of Engineering and Technology. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: DC grid; Droop control; Low-bandwidth communication; Output impedance; Virtual inertia
Index Keywords: Electric impedance; Electric load flow; Electric power transmission networks; MATLAB; Stochastic systems; System stability; Virtual storage; DC grid; Droop control; Low-bandwidth communications; Output impedance; Virtual inertia; Quality control

Authors: Wu T., Li G., Bie Z.
Title: Power procurement strategies of retailer considering demand response program
Source title: IET Conference Publications
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an, China; Department of Electrical Engineering, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an, China; Department of Electrical Engineering, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an, China

Abstract: For electricity retailers, the decision-making of energy procurement and sale has become the core issue of operation. In this paper, an energy management model of the electricity retailer in smart grids has been proposed. Multiple energy procurement sources contain pool market (PM), bilateral contracts (BCs), renewable energy sources (photovoltaic (PV) system and wind turbine (WT)). In addition, electric vehicles (EVs), energy storage system (ESS) and demand response program (DRP), are considered for the retailer to reduce the energy procurement cost and to improve the operational risk resistance ability. In the proposed model, objective functions are established from the perspective of the retailer and end-consumers respectively. To validate the proposed model, a case study is conducted and the results are analysed to draw the conclusions. © 2019 Institution of Engineering and Technology. All rights reserved.

Authors: Gui Q., Su H., Feng D., Zhou Y., Xu R., Yan Z., Lei T.
Title: A novel linear battery energy storage system (BESS) life loss calculation model for BESS-integrated wind farm in scheduled power tracking
Source title: IET Conference Publications
Affiliations: Key Laboratory of Control of Power Transmission and Conversion, Ministry of Education, Department of Electrical Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, 800 Dongchuan Rd., Shanghai, China; Marketing Department, State Grid Shanghai Municipal Electric Power Company, 1122 Yuansheng Rd., Shanghai, China
Authors with affiliations: Gui, Q., Key Laboratory of Control of Power Transmission and Conversion, Ministry of Education, Department of Electrical Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, 800 Dongchuan Rd., Shanghai, China; Su, H., Key Laboratory of Control of Power Transmission and Conversion, Ministry of Education, Department of Electrical Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, 800 Dongchuan Rd., Shanghai, China; Feng, D., Key Laboratory of Control of Power Transmission and Conversion, Ministry of Education, Department of Electrical Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, 800 Dongchuan Rd., Shanghai, China; Zhou, Y., Key Laboratory of Control of Power Transmission and Conversion, Ministry of Education, Department of Electrical Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, 800 Dongchuan Rd., Shanghai, China; Xu, R., Key Laboratory of Control of Power Transmission and Conversion, Ministry of Education, Department of Electrical Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, 800 Dongchuan Rd., Shanghai, China; Yan, Z., Key Laboratory of Control of Power Transmission and Conversion, Ministry of Education, Department of Electrical Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, 800 Dongchuan Rd., Shanghai, China; Lei, T., Marketing Department, State Grid Shanghai Municipal Electric Power Company, 1122 Yuansheng Rd., Shanghai, China
Abstract: Recently, rapid development of battery technology makes it feasible to integrate renewable generations with battery energy storage system (BESS). The consideration of BESS life loss for different BESS application scenarios is economic imperative. In this paper, a novel linear BESS life loss calculation model for BESS-integrated wind farm in scheduled power tracking is proposed. Firstly, based on the life cycle times-depth of discharge (DOD) relation-curve, the BESS life loss coefficient for unit throughput energy with different state of charge (SOC) can be determined from the life cycle times-DOD relation-curve fitting function directly. Secondly, as unidirectional variation of SOC in a single time step, the BESS life loss can be calculated through integration of the life loss coefficient-SOC relation function. A linear BESS life loss calculation model is established through self-optimal piecewise linearization of the primitive function of the life loss coefficient-SOC relation function. Thirdly, the proposed life loss calculation model is incorporated in the BESS-integrated wind farm scheduled power tracking optimization. Case studies demonstrate that with the proposed method, the BESS life loss item can be incorporated in the optimization model effectively, and the scheduled power tracking cost of the BESS-integrated wind farm can be determined and optimized more comprehensively. © 2019 Institution of Engineering and Technology. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Battery Energy Storage System; Life Loss Calculation Model; Scheduled Power Tracking; Self-Optimal Piecewise Linearization; Wind Farm
Index Keywords: Charging (batteries); Clustering algorithms; Curve fitting; Electric power system interconnection; Electric utilities; Life cycle; Linearization; Secondary batteries; Wind power; Battery energy storage systems; Loss calculation; Piecewise linearization; Power tracking; Wind farm; Battery storage

Authors: Adefarati T., Bansal R.C., Naidoo R.
Title: Design of an energy management scheme for residential demand response in a microgrid system
Source title: IET Conference Publications
Affiliations: Department of Electrical, Electronic and Computer Engineering, University of Pretoria, South Africa; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Sharjah, Sharjah, United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: Adefarati, T., Department of Electrical, Electronic and Computer Engineering, University of Pretoria, South Africa; Bansal, R.C., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Sharjah, Sharjah, United Arab Emirates; Naidoo, R., Department of Electrical, Electronic and Computer Engineering, University of Pretoria, South Africa
Abstract: The fluctuating prices of fossil fuels coupled with other technical and economic limitations have compelled the utilities to use renewable energy technologies (RETs) for power generation. In view of this, the physical accessibility of solar and wind resources has encouraged the application of RETs in the microgrid (MG) systems. The feasibility assessment of a MG system is investigated in this work with the aim of promoting the photovoltaic (PV), wind turbine (WT) and battery storage system (BSS) for power generation application in a standalone MG system. The optimal configuration of a MG system is achieved with the application of an fmincon optimization function. The research work is carried out by using a typical load profile of low-medium sized residential buildings in Cape Town, South Africa. This study is designed to evaluate the technical and financial viability of a MG system. This leads to the minimization of the net present cost (NPC) and cost of energy (COE) as well as the maximization of cost of net energy purchased, benefit and benefit-cost ratio (BCR). It can be established from the outcomes of the study that green technologies are the cost-effective means of accomplishing sustainable energy goal. © 2019 Institution of Engineering and Technology. All rights reserved.

Authors: Scharinger-Urschitz G., Walter H., Bauernfeind T.
Title: Novel fin geometry for a latent high temperature thermal energy storage - Experimental investigation
Source title: Proceedings of the Thermal and Fluids Engineering Summer Conference
Affiliations: Institute for Energy Systems and Thermodynamic, TU Wien, Getreidemarkt 9, Wien, 1060, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Scharinger-Urschitz, G., Institute for Energy Systems and Thermodynamic, TU Wien, Getreidemarkt 9, Wien, 1060, Austria; Walter, H., Institute for Energy Systems and Thermodynamic, TU Wien, Getreidemarkt 9, Wien, 1060, Austria; Bauernfeind, T., Institute for Energy Systems and Thermodynamic, TU Wien, Getreidemarkt 9, Wien, 1060, Austria
Abstract: Thermal energy storage technology can balance volatile energy production as well as power consumption by increasing thermal power plant flexibilities. Therefore, an experimental investigation with latent heat thermal energy storage, utilizing sodium nitrate (NaNO3) with a melting point of 306 °C as phase change material, was carried out in the present study. The heat source and sink for the experimental setup is a thermal oil plant using Therminol VP1® as heat transfer fluid. To increase the heat flux into the storage material, a bimetal tube consisting of a circular steel tube and an aluminum tube with fins was used. The storage operates around the melting point to use the enthalpy of fusion as primary storage mechanism. The temperature distribution in the storage is measured, as well as the heat transfer fluid temperatures and mass flow. For the experiment a novel fin-geometry, based on the combination of transversal and longitudinal fins, was introduced. A more than 40 % lower melting time compared to former fin geometries (equal bimetal tube with only longitudinal fins) was observed. The heat transmission coefficient from the heat transfer fluid into the storage material was determined. Storage parameters like power, capacity and heat losses to the surrounding were logged. Different mass flows of the heat transfer fluid and different temperature spreads were tested in order to determine the storage behavior. Reliable storage parameters for the latent thermal energy storage were gained. © 2019 Begell House Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Bimetal finned tubes; Fin geometry; Heat transfer coefficient; Heat transfer enhancement; NaNO3; Phase change material; Thermal energy storage

Authors: Jing X., Yu L., Qi Y., Jianting Z., Wentao H.
Title: Research on information interaction mechanism of plug-and-play of battery energy storage system
Source title: IET Conference Publications
Affiliations: Shinan Power Supply Company of State Grid Shanghai Municipal Electric Power Company, Shanghai Yishan Road 1651200233, China; Shanghai Jiaotong University, Shanghai Dongchuan Road 800200240, China
Authors with affiliations: Jing, X., Shinan Power Supply Company of State Grid Shanghai Municipal Electric Power Company, Shanghai Yishan Road 1651200233, China; Yu, L., Shinan Power Supply Company of State Grid Shanghai Municipal Electric Power Company, Shanghai Yishan Road 1651200233, China; Qi, Y., Shinan Power Supply Company of State Grid Shanghai Municipal Electric Power Company, Shanghai Yishan Road 1651200233, China; Jianting, Z., Shinan Power Supply Company of State Grid Shanghai Municipal Electric Power Company, Shanghai Yishan Road 1651200233, China; Wentao, H., Shanghai Jiaotong University, Shanghai Dongchuan Road 800200240, China
Abstract: With the large-scale application of distributed generators, how to realize self-description and interoperability is a difficult point of plug-and-play information interaction technology. Taking BESS as the research object, a plug-and-play information interaction mechanism is established according to IEC61850 communication model and protocol mapping. The mechanism is based on information modeling and self-description of the terminal-layer device. The mapping relationship between IEC61850 meta-model and IEC60870-5-104 protocol is formed by extending IEC61850 meta-model. The heterogeneous model mapping and data conversion module is designed for interactive data conversion between IEC61850 information and IEC61968 message. In this way, the information interaction path between the master station layer and the terminal layer is formed. On that basis, a plug-and-play information interaction architecture is established. The architecture consists of three parts: the monitoring master station layer, the distributed terminal layer and the communication network. Taking a typical feeder segment from distribution network as a case, the consistency test is conducted to verify the validity of the self-describing information and the information interaction mechanism. © 2019 Institution of Engineering and Technology. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Bess; Distributed generators; IEC61850/IEC61968; Information Interaction; Plug-and-Play
Index Keywords: Data handling; Digital storage; Distributed power generation; Electric batteries; Electric substations; Information theory; Interoperability; Mapping; Network architecture; Bess; Distributed generators; IEC 61850; Information interaction; Plug and play; Battery storage

Authors: Tian K., Ali S., Huang Z., Ling Z.
Title: Power control and experiment of 2MW/10kV cascaded H-bridge power conversion system for battery energy storage system
Source title: IET Conference Publications
Affiliations: Key Laboratory of Control of Power Transmission and Conversion, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China
Authors with affiliations: Tian, K., Key Laboratory of Control of Power Transmission and Conversion, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China; Ali, S., Key Laboratory of Control of Power Transmission and Conversion, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China; Huang, Z., Key Laboratory of Control of Power Transmission and Conversion, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China; Ling, Z., Key Laboratory of Control of Power Transmission and Conversion, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, China
Abstract: Renewable energy sources such as photovoltaic and wind turbine power generators may make the power grid unstable because of their output fluctuations. Battery energy storage systems (BESSs) are being considered as a countermeasure for this issue. Cascaded H-bridge (CHB) is expected as a promising topology for large capacity BESSs because the state of charge (SOC) of battery clusters can be controlled independently by H-bridge power units, and the harmonic current of the system is low enough to remove the ac filter. This paper describes the development of the Y-connection CHB-BESS and a power control strategy for the BESS. A real-scale 2MW/10kV CHB-BESS was constructed in Shenzhen, China and its successful operation verify the effectiveness of the proposed control method. Based on the system, the power control strategy was verified by three parts of the experiment, which are decoupling power control test, emergency shutdown test and step response test. The results indicate that the system can realize decoupling control of active and reactive power effectively, achieve step response at the millisecond level and make full-load shutdown in an emergency state at the microsecond level. © 2019 Institution of Engineering and Technology. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Battery energy storage system(BESS); Cascaded H-Bridge(CHB); Power control strategy; Power conversion system

Authors: Ge Y., Wang L., He Y., Li B., Huang J.
Title: Feasibility study on energy storage replacing external power supply based on sequential operating simulation method
Source title: IET Conference Publications
Affiliations: State Grid Jiangsu Economic Research Institute, 251 Zhongshan Road, Nanjing, China; China Energy Engineering Group Jiangsu Power Design Institute, 58 Suyuan Road, Nanjing, China

Abstract: In recent years, China's energy storage industry has shown a good development trend, especially the electrochemical energy storage performance continues to improve, and the cost continues to decline. According to the analysis and prediction of authoritative organizations, the cost of electrochemical energy storage will continue to decline rapidly in the future, and the cycle life of batteries will gradually increase. It is possible to commercialize large-scale electrochemical energy storage. Considering the constraints of energy resources and transportation conditions in Jiangsu Province, as well as the constraints of environmental capacity on the development of local power supply, regional external electricity has become an important power supply in Jiangsu Province. This paper considers the development of large-scale energy storage and substitutes for a DC transmission system and analyses its operation. Some research directions and preliminary theoretical calculation references for the possible application of large capacity energy storage in power system in the future are proposed. It provides the necessary basis for provincial power grid to promote energy production and consumption revolution in the future, and explores the feasibility of further supporting the development and application of energy storage industry. © 2019 Institution of Engineering and Technology. All rights reserved.

Authors: Shu Z., Peng X., Zhao Y., Huang S., Zhang Z., Li H.
Title: A control strategy for battery energy storage smoothing short-term wind power fluctuation based on ANN
Source title: IET Conference Publications
Affiliations: Jiang Xi Electric Power Research Institute, Nanchang, 330096, China; School of Electrical Engineering and Automation, Wuhan University, Wuhan, 430072, China
Authors with affiliations: Shu, Z., Jiang Xi Electric Power Research Institute, Nanchang, 330096, China; Peng, X., School of Electrical Engineering and Automation, Wuhan University, Wuhan, 430072, China; Zhao, Y., Jiang Xi Electric Power Research Institute, Nanchang, 330096, China; Huang, S., School of Electrical Engineering and Automation, Wuhan University, Wuhan, 430072, China; Zhang, Z., School of Electrical Engineering and Automation, Wuhan University, Wuhan, 430072, China; Li, H., School of Electrical Engineering and Automation, Wuhan University, Wuhan, 430072, China
Abstract: With the Grid-connected scale of wind generators increasing, the random fluctuation of wind power has been one of the critical issues for the consumption of wind power. From the perspective of how to use the battery energy storage system (BESS) to smooth the wind power fluctuation, the control scheme for two BESSs using the alternative charging/discharging strategy to smooth the wind power fluctuation is proposed at first. Then, the design method for determining the capacity of the two BESSs based on the statistics of wind power fluctuation is studied. Due to the adaptive neural network (ANN) has the excellent ability in setting up the non-linear mapping between the input and output of the controlled object whose model is difficult for building, the ANN is therefore used to generate the reference command for BESSs smoothing the short-term and strongly random wind power fluctuation. At the same time, the improved method for adaptively adjusting the weight of neurons based on modifying deviation latch is proposed to improve the accuracy of ANN on predicting the short term wind power fluctuation. Finally, both the feasibility of both the proposed charging and discharging strategy in saving the battery cycle life and the effectiveness of the proposed ANN control strategy in smoothing the short-term wind power fluctuation is validated by simulating in the improved 11-bus wind power system. © 2019 Institution of Engineering and Technology. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Adaptive neural network; Energy storage system; Power fluctuation smoothing; Wind power prediction; Wind power system
Index Keywords: Charging (batteries); Data storage equipment; Secondary batteries; Wind power; Adaptive neural networks; Battery energy storage; Battery energy storage systems; Charging/discharging; Energy storage systems; Power fluctuations; Wind generator systems; Wind power predictions; Battery storage

Authors: Singh A.R., Ding L., Kumar A., Kheshti M., Singh R., Bansal R.
Title: Isolated microgrid voltage regulation using fuzzy-logic based inverter control
Source title: IET Conference Publications
Affiliations: School of Electrical Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, China; College of Electrical Engineering, Zhejiang University, China; Department of EECE, University of Pretoria, Pretoria, South Africa; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Sharjah, Sharjah, United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: Singh, A.R., School of Electrical Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, China; Ding, L., School of Electrical Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, China; Kumar, A., College of Electrical Engineering, Zhejiang University, China; Kheshti, M., School of Electrical Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, China; Singh, R., Department of EECE, University of Pretoria, Pretoria, South Africa; Bansal, R., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Sharjah, Sharjah, United Arab Emirates
Abstract: Modern isolated microgrid requires flexible and intelligent control of inverter to minimize the power mismatch between renewable generators and load. Maintaining the voltage at load connection is one of the critical aspects of voltage regulation in the isolated microgrid. The power generation from renewable generators is not constant as well as load parameters. Also, the power flow control between renewable generators is another major issue in an isolated microgrid. In this study, the intelligent fuzzy-logic based inverter control (FLIC) is used to regulate the voltage at the load connected considered the change in load-parameter and variation in the renewable power generation. The power output from the renewable generators is converted in DC to make the DC-bus, which helps to maintain the power flow control between renewable generators and battery storage. The variation in the DC bus voltage is kept within acceptable limit using PI battery controller. The FLIC uses the error in the reference voltage and difference between the line-to-line voltage to generate firing pulses based on if-then rules. PV and renewable wind generator modeled with MPPT control for optimal power generation. © 2019 Institution of Engineering and Technology. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Fuzzy interface; Isolated microgrid; Renewable energy resources; Voltage regulation

Title: Carbon Materials as the Matrices for Sulfur in Li-S Batteries

Abstract: Development of advanced energy-storage batteries for portable electronic devices and electric vehicles must accomplish several requirements: Safety, low-cost, nature friendly, long lifecycle, high energy density, and high theoretical capacity. Lithium-sulfur batteries can execute these requirements. However, the practical application of lithium-sulfur battery is hindered by several major disabilities, such as volumetric expansion of sulfur, structural instability, high self-discharging, poor electronic conductivity of sulfur, and low cycle life. This article deals with different types of carbons as additives in cathode for lithium-sulfur battery. © The Electrochemical Society.

Authors: Maca J., Sedlarikova M., Libich J., Kazda T., Jasso K.
Title: Ceramic based negative electrode for sodium ion accumulators
Source title: ECS Transactions

Authors with affiliations: Maca, J., Brno University of Technology, Technicka 10, Brno, 616 00, Czech Republic; Sedlarikova, M., Brno University of Technology, Technicka 10, Brno, 616 00, Czech Republic; Libich, J., Brno University of Technology, Technicka 10, Brno, 616 00, Czech Republic; Kazda, T., Brno University of Technology, Technicka 10, Brno, 616 00, Czech Republic; Jasso, K., Brno University of Technology, Technicka 10, Brno, 616 00, Czech Republic
Abstract: Energetics is one of the main areas which the humanity is deal with. The mobility development brought the accumulators as a power source for them. To the most common used accumulators belong lead acid accumulators which can be found in almost all cars. The second used type is lithium ion accumulators. Lithium ion accumulators are used in many applications such as stationary storages, power supply for small mobile devices like phones, laptops, small power tools and also as energy sources in electro cars. The main disadvantages of lithium are high price and relatively rarity in earth's crust. This paper, focus on composition optimization of negative electrode material for sodium ion accumulators. The sodium metatitanate is used as base electrode material and the ratio of conductive components is changed. The optimal composition for best material performance was established. © The Electrochemical Society.
Index Keywords: Electrochemical electrodes; Lithium; Metal ions; Structural geology; Composition optimization; Earth's crust; Electrode material; Lithium-ion accumulators; Material performance; Negative electrode; Negative electrode material; Optimal composition; Sodium compounds

Authors: Cunningham L.
Title: “Mind the Gap” between old and new nuclear qualified cable: Lessons learned from aging, historical adverse events and other nuclear cable issues
Source title: 19th International Conference on Environmental Degradation of Materials in Nuclear Power Systems - Water Reactors, EnvDeg 2019
Affiliations: CableLAN Nuclear
Authors with affiliations: Cunningham, L., CableLAN Nuclear
Abstract: Nuclear-qualified cable designs have been available since the 1970s. Though their polymeric formulations may still be considered as sophisticated today, compounds are presently being formulated to meet more rigorous requirements or due to restrictions in compound ingredient use. The Technical and Quality requirements of Environmental Qualification have also evolved as improvements to reduce risk, sometimes initiated in response to adverse events involving cables or perhaps to meet the rigors of new advanced reactor designs. Legacy plants have qualified, aged cable near retirement or life extension and may require condition monitoring. Some of the new cable designs have improved materials, construction and advancements. Regulations have been developed and improved upon for various reasons to better assure public safety. There have been examples of gaps - but still in compliance - in considering the Technical or the Quality requirements of the Environmental Qualification to which the cable is qualified, how well the Environment was defined, how it the cable was installed. Examples discussed include risks from shipping, storage or installation of cable, cable submergence as an unforeseen environment and the post LOCA severe accident condition. This paper will review the history of US nuclear cable use and issues. The author suggests mindfulness in gaps and cable-specific recommendations for use at the new, advanced reactor designs. © 2019 19th International Conference on Environmental Degradation of Materials in Nuclear Power Systems - Water Reactors, EnvDeg. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Condition monitoring; Nuclear energy; Nuclear fuels; Nuclear reactor accidents; Advanced reactor design; Adverse events; Cable design; Environmental qualification; Polymeric formulations; Public safety; Quality requirements; Severe accident; Cables

Authors: Cao C., Chen J., Xu C., Zhang P., Lin Y., Ge H.
Title: A new type of device used on deep-sea submarine terrain monitoring
Source title: Proceedings of the International Offshore and Polar Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Ocean college, Zhejiang University, Zhoushan, Zhejiang, China
Authors with affiliations: Cao, C., Ocean college, Zhejiang University, Zhoushan, Zhejiang, China; Chen, J., Ocean college, Zhejiang University, Zhoushan, Zhejiang, China; Xu, C., Ocean college, Zhejiang University, Zhoushan, Zhejiang, China; Zhang, P., Ocean college, Zhejiang University, Zhoushan, Zhejiang, China; Lin, Y., Ocean college, Zhejiang University, Zhoushan, Zhejiang, China; Ge, H., Ocean college, Zhejiang University, Zhoushan, Zhejiang, China
Abstract: As an important green energy source, the presence of gas hydrates very demanding. They are only found on the seabed at a depth of kilometer. Large-scale exploitation of natural gas hydrates is likely to cause dramatic changes in the seabed topography, resulting in certain risks. Therefore, it is necessary to carry out in-situ on-line monitoring of the terrain while mining. Based on the above considerations, this paper designs a device for terrain monitoring of gas hydrate test mining area. Taking into account the complexity of the marine environment and the difficulty of submarine operations, the design uses a winch as the underwater control center, the MEMS accelerometer is placed in a cylindrical pressure chamber, and multiple sensors in the same direction form a sensor array with a coil wound on the winch. The ROV robot is used for stretching and is distributed by the motor to drive the drum to rotate. In order to ensure the reliability of long-distance data transmission and simplify the circuit, the design uses RS-485 (RS-485 is a serial bus standard that uses balanced transmit and differential receive.) for communication, and the data is transmitted to the upper computer for reconstruction to obtain the terrain of the test mining area. In the end, two experiments were designed to simulate the operation of the device on the seabed, which proved that the device can work normally under the complicated conditions of the seabed. © 2019 by the International Society of Offshore and Polar Engineers (ISOPE).
Author Keywords: Gas hydrate; MEMS accelerometer; Submarine terrain monitoring; Terrain reconstruction

Authors: Tan Z., Chen S., Lin H., Luo L., Zeng Y.
Title: Ship intelligent energy efficiency management system design
Source title: Proceedings of the International Offshore and Polar Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Naval Architecture and Ocean Engineering, School of Transportation, Wuhan University of Technology, Wuhan, Hubei Province, China
Authors with affiliations: Tan, Z., Naval Architecture and Ocean Engineering, School of Transportation, Wuhan University of Technology, Wuhan, Hubei Province, China; Chen, S., Naval Architecture and Ocean Engineering, School of Transportation, Wuhan University of Technology, Wuhan, Hubei Province, China; Lin, H., Naval Architecture and Ocean Engineering, School of Transportation, Wuhan University of Technology, Wuhan, Hubei Province, China; Luo, L., Naval Architecture and Ocean Engineering, School of Transportation, Wuhan University of Technology, Wuhan, Hubei Province, China; Zeng, Y., Naval Architecture and Ocean Engineering, School of Transportation, Wuhan University of Technology, Wuhan, Hubei Province, China
Abstract: The shipbuilding industry is accelerating its intelligent process in a world where artificial intelligence, big data, Internet of Things, cloud computing are experiencing rapid development and wide adaptation in various industries. Today’s intelligent ships can be roughly divided into six modules: intelligent navigation, intelligent hull, intelligent cabin, intelligent energy efficiency, intelligent cargo management, and intelligent integration platform. This paper targets intelligent energy efficiency and develops a practical software system for energy efficiency monitoring and management. An HMI-friendly integrated system of data monitoring, acquisition, analysis, storage and backup running on the Windows platform, this design uses Visual C#.NET as a development tool and conducts class-based object-oriented programming. The software adopts the MODBUS-RTU protocol and the NEMA-0183 protocol to conduct software-hardware data communication and stores data in the SQL server database. In order to ensure the security of ship data, the system backups both hardware and software data: RAID disk array technology on the hardware level and on the software level synchronous replication which remotely synchronizes data to shore-based databases through 4G networks and which performs a second backup to facilitate the monitoring operation of shore personnel. Also the speed optimization module of the system processes and conducts analysis of the collected data and arrives at an optimal speed that improves energy efficiency and reduces emission. © 2019 by the International Society of Offshore and Polar Engineers (ISOPE).
Author Keywords: Energy efficiency data analysis; Intelligent ship; Ship energy efficiency management; Speed optimization

Authors: Thrampoulidis E., Mavromatidis G., Lucchi A., Orehounig K.
Title: Could machine learning be used to approximate optimal building retrofit solutions with the use of easily accessible building data?
Source title: ECOS 2019 - Proceedings of the 32nd International Conference on Efficiency, Cost, Optimization, Simulation and Environmental Impact of Energy Systems
Affiliations: Laboratory for Urban Energy Systems, Empa Duebendorf, Switzerland; ETH Zurich, Switzerland; Institute for Machine Learning, Data analytics lab, ETH Zurich, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Thrampoulidis, E., Laboratory for Urban Energy Systems, Empa Duebendorf, Switzerland; Mavromatidis, G., ETH Zurich, Switzerland; Lucchi, A., Institute for Machine Learning, Data analytics lab, ETH Zurich, Switzerland; Orehounig, K., Laboratory for Urban Energy Systems, Empa Duebendorf, Switzerland
Abstract: Building retrofit is of greatest importance to reduce the environmental footprint of the building stock. It typically refers to two types of interventions: the first pertaining to interventions on the building envelope, for instance by enhancing the thermal insulation of a building’s walls, and the second to energy system replacements. The latter includes not only the installation of a more efficient heating system, with the necessary capacity to meet the building's heat demands, but also the integration of renewable energy technologies and energy storage. Thus, there is a huge array of retrofit measure combinations to select from with different economic and environmental impacts. Even though there are tools and methodologies to handle the complex problem of deriving optimal retrofit solutions, they typically require increased level of expertise and highly heterogeneous building data, which are usually not available or challenging to obtain. As a result, building owners can find themselves in a quandary about how to further proceed with retrofitting their buildings. In this paper, we answer the question whether a machine-learning algorithm could be used as a surrogate model that can: (a) mimic the functionality of the retrofit process, and (b) derive near-optimal solutions with the use of building features that can be easily extracted, such as the building's ground floor area or age. To answer this question an artificial neural network-based model is trained with data collected from the case study of the city of Zurich. Results show that the proposed approach can approximate very well some dimensions of the building retrofit, such as the retrofit costs (R2 ≅ 0.971) and the energy system selection (f1 score ≅ 0.894), while for others, such as the electricity storage capacity (R2 ≅ 0.505), there is still room for improvement. Such surrogate retrofit models can be more easily shared with building owners, and can contribute towards accelerating the adoption of retrofit measures. © ECOS 2019 - Proceedings of the 32nd International Conference on Efficiency, Cost, Optimization, Simulation and Environmental Impact of Energy Systems. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Machine learning; Multi-objective optimization; Pareto-optimal; Renewables integration; Retrofit

Authors: Pavičević M., Nijs W., Kavvadias K., Quoilin S.
Title: Modelling flexible power demand and supply in the EU power system: Soft-linking between JRCEU-TIMES and the open-source Dispa-SET model
Source title: ECOS 2019 - Proceedings of the 32nd International Conference on Efficiency, Cost, Optimization, Simulation and Environmental Impact of Energy Systems
Affiliations: KU Leuven – Faculty of engineering technology, Geel, Belgium; European Commission - Joint research centre, Peten, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Pavičević, M., KU Leuven – Faculty of engineering technology, Geel, Belgium; Nijs, W., European Commission - Joint research centre, Peten, Netherlands; Kavvadias, K., European Commission - Joint research centre, Peten, Netherlands; Quoilin, S., KU Leuven – Faculty of engineering technology, Geel, Belgium
Abstract: Modelling the variability of renewable energy sources together with flexible and/or storage technologies is highly relevant for the current EU power system. Dispa-SET is an open-source unit commitment and optimal dispatch model that covers various energy sectors (power systems, heating & cooling, transportation) and the 26 European countries plus Switzerland and Norway. It uses high-resolution time series for the demands, renewable generation and outages to optimize the system operation under technical constraints (e.g. maximum ramping rates of power plants, interconnection capacities, heating & cooling constraints, etc.). This work evaluates the application of the model on the ENTSOE EU28 open-dataset and calibrates critical inputs such as renewables availability, power plant outages, hydro levels and power demands to match historic data for the year 2016. The calibrated model is finally used to assess the implementation of future low carbon EU strategies and policies through several “what if” scenarios and soft linking with the JRC-EU-TIMES model. © ECOS 2019 - Proceedings of the 32nd International Conference on Efficiency, Cost, Optimization, Simulation and Environmental Impact of Energy Systems. All rights reserved.

Authors: Tshamala M.C., Peter Edlmann F.R.
Title: Feasibility study of a low-cost wind powered air-cooling system for rural communities
Source title: ECOS 2019 - Proceedings of the 32nd International Conference on Efficiency, Cost, Optimization, Simulation and Environmental Impact of Energy Systems
Affiliations: Stellenbosch University, Stellenbosch, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Tshamala, M.C., Stellenbosch University, Stellenbosch, South Africa; Peter Edlmann, F.R.
Abstract: This article considers the potential for success of a wind powered air-cooling system for use in cooling a low-cost house by comparing the power demand of the system with wind velocity supply. Historical weather data is combined with fundamental principles of heat transfer to theoretically determine the cooling load of a low-cost house. Fundamental principles of heat transfer are used in the investigation. Wind velocity data is used to investigate the potential of wind as a source of power to drive the system. The feasibility of the wind powered air-cooling system is established by comparing the daily trends for the power required by the wind powered air-cooling system with the wind velocity trends. The system is found to be feasible, with wind availability able to meet the power demand to cool the low-cost house. Future work should focus on selecting a wind turbine configuration to apply to such a system, to model the power outputs of the turbine. This will further validate the potential for success of such systems. © ECOS 2019 - Proceedings of the 32nd International Conference on Efficiency, Cost, Optimization, Simulation and Environmental Impact of Energy Systems. All rights reserved.

Authors: Fadlelseed K., Mohamed O.-E.E.
Title: Modelling and simulation of solar-powered absorption cooling system – a case study of Khartoum, Sudan
Source title: ECOS 2019 - Proceedings of the 32nd International Conference on Efficiency, Cost, Optimization, Simulation and Environmental Impact of Energy Systems
Affiliations: Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, University of Khartoum, Khartoum, Sudan
Authors with affiliations: Fadlelseed, K., Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, University of Khartoum, Khartoum, Sudan; Mohamed, O.-E.E., Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, University of Khartoum, Khartoum, Sudan
Abstract: Instability of electricity supply in many developing countries is an increasing problem, especially during the summer when the demand for refrigeration and air-conditioning increases. To mitigate this problem various research have been conducted worldwide to find alternative energy resources to power the refrigeration and the air-conditioning systems. The main aim of this research is to assess the potential of operating a solar-powered cooling system in Khartoum, Sudan. A solar-powered air-conditioning system consists of a single effect Lithium Bromide water absorption system, a flat plate collector and a fully mixed storage tank, was developed. The investigated system was simulated using the engineering equation solver (EES) software with meteorological data containing the weather parameters of the Khartoum city. The proposed system was developed to air condition an office of a maximum cooling load capacity of approximately one ton of refrigeration (3.517 kW) and working from 7:00 to 16:00. The performance of the system was assessed for the months from May through October considering an air conditioning chiller operated with a generator temperature ranging from 65 °C to 95 °C. The obtained results indicate that the performance of the proposed system, within the considered generator temperature range, is acceptable. The coefficient of performance of the developed absorption system ranges from 0.71 to 0.73. Overall, the research reveals that a solar-powered absorption refrigeration Lithium Bromide water cooling system can successfully be operated in Khartoum city. © ECOS 2019 - Proceedings of the 32nd International Conference on Efficiency, Cost, Optimization, Simulation and Environmental Impact of Energy Systems. All rights reserved.

Authors: Zeneli M., Nikolopoulos A., Nikolopoulos N., Karellas S., Kakaras E.
Title: Study of vessel shape effect on charge/discharge rates of a silicon-based LHTES system
Source title: ECOS 2019 - Proceedings of the 32nd International Conference on Efficiency, Cost, Optimization, Simulation and Environmental Impact of Energy Systems
Affiliations: Centre for Research and Technology Hellas, Chemical Process and Energy Resources Institute (CERTH/CPERI), Athens, Greece; Laboratory of Steam Boilers and Thermal Plants, National Technical University of Athens 9, Zografou, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Zeneli, M., Centre for Research and Technology Hellas, Chemical Process and Energy Resources Institute (CERTH/CPERI), Athens, Greece; Nikolopoulos, A., Centre for Research and Technology Hellas, Chemical Process and Energy Resources Institute (CERTH/CPERI), Athens, Greece; Nikolopoulos, N., Centre for Research and Technology Hellas, Chemical Process and Energy Resources Institute (CERTH/CPERI), Athens, Greece; Karellas, S., Laboratory of Steam Boilers and Thermal Plants, National Technical University of Athens 9, Zografou, Greece; Kakaras, E., Centre for Research and Technology Hellas, Chemical Process and Energy Resources Institute (CERTH/CPERI), Athens, Greece
Abstract: This work presents a validated computational fluid dynamics (CFD) model able to simulate the solidification/melting process of high energy density phase-change materials (PCM), such as silicon. Storage devices utilizing such PCMs can be used in power-to-heat-to-power (P2H2P) systems, to store heat in high temperature and use it for electricity production. Prior to manufacturing such a device, there is a necessity to scrutinize the complex heat transfer mechanisms occurring during the phase change of the contained PCM and indicate a flexible vessel design that enables quick charge/discharge rates and low heat losses during storage period. The CFD model, which is developed in Fluent v17.0 platform, combines the volume of fluid method with the enthalpy porosity approach and an adaptive local grid refinement method, able to achieve a sharp gas/PCM and solid/liquid PCM interface. In contrast to analytical or other CFD models available in the literature, this one takes into account the PCM volume change during solidification/melting, possible dendrites formation and buoyancy-driven natural convection effect on heat transfer mechanisms. Numerical results unveil that the system charge/discharge rates are highly dependent on the PCM permeability and vessel design. Between five shapes investigated, i.e. cylinder, cube, truncated cone, sphere and cut-off sphere, of volume Vvessel=3.75E-03 m3, the truncated cone is the most suitable solution for a P2H2P application, considering design flexibility, melting rates and heat losses. Actually, the PCM melting time achieved with the cone is 21% quicker compared to sphere and only 6% slower compared to cube; the latter is the optimum geometry, as concerns charge rates, but it should be avoided because of its excess lateral losses during storage period. During discharging, when heat is extracted from the vessel bottom, the truncated cone results in the lowest solidification rates, almost 50% lower than the cut-off sphere, which is the optimum shape in terms of discharge rates. Nevertheless, the truncated-cone discharge rates can be further improved by altering its height, without increasing its volume. In practice, the current model is of high accuracy and can give optimization guidelines for the design of such and similar LHTES systems. © ECOS 2019 - Proceedings of the 32nd International Conference on Efficiency, Cost, Optimization, Simulation and Environmental Impact of Energy Systems. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Computational fluid dynamics (CFD); Silicon solidification/melting; Vessel shape investigation; Volume of fluid method
